post:
I've always read that cooked rice eaten next day is potentially lethal. However.... many years of experience tells me that out of the fridge and dumped into a very hot frying pan with onions, followed a few minutes later with a few odd veggies lying around and finished off with a good glug of soy sauce makes an excellent fried rice that so far   hasn't killed me off.   
The key thing is to get the rice into the hot pan before too much else is added to cool it down. So oil and (optional) onions/garlic first. Once the pan is sizzling, get the rice in and bang up the heat to keep the temperature high. You get a sort of feel for when the pan is hot enough to have killed off anything dangerous in the rice. After that point, add anything else you want.

Without going into the whole Zen of the perfect coffee thing, the two  factors in the taste of a coffee are: 
1) What beans you use. 
2) How recently those beans were ground.   
As to the machines, I've got through two myself in about 21 years, but I also happen to be the kind of guy who people say "You're a handy type of guy, would you have a look at our coffee maker, the shop says it can't be repaired?", so I've probably had about 25 of them apart over the years.   
Even amongst the top brands, some are just not very well designed, but some are real workhorses which are relatively easy to put back into service.   
Of the ones that I could return to service the three most common faults are 
1) Lack of cleaning of the machine. 
2) Damage to the control system or sensors. 
3) Grinder becoming caked up with bean powder.   
If you buy a machine with a weak mechanism and never brush the coffee powder off the mechanism, and vacuum out all the grounds, then the mechanism will eventually give in.   
If you aren't careful with filling the water reservoir then the moisture which ends up inside the machine will eventually do do the hoo hooey on you.   
To clean the caked powder out of the grinder you usually need to completely disassemble the machine. The cleaning is pretty straightforward, but getting to the bits which need cleaning takes a bit of time and a fair portion of jiggery pokery.   
When you are looking at the bottom of the market, go to a shop which has the top of the line ones as well and compare the mechanism. Some of the bottom of the line models are pretty straight clones of the more expensive ones, the easy way to spot this is to put the mechanisms side by side.

Actually, Simply Jif is the only Jif for me. No added palm oil (ok, 2% or less rapeseed or soy is the claim on the label). post:
That is the killer for any glass/porcelain enamelled metal surface. Putting a cold enamelled pot onto a hot element, filling a hot pot with something cold, quenching the pot while hot will eventually cause the glaze to separate from the metal. The problem is that the glaze and the metal contract at two different rates, heating or cooling the item rapidly sets up a tension in the boundary layer between the two materials.   
Not to divert every single thread into one about cars, but the exhaust manifolds on Jaguar and quite a few other classic cars are covered with porcelain enamel. They used to last a lot longer, but some of the materials used in the glaze are highly toxic and no longer used by the companies which use them, so although you can have them reglazed, they don't last much longer than about 3 years regardless of how carefully one treats them.

A little bit of cheese fondue chemistry .   
Is lemon juice required? Answer: No if you have the right wine.    
The right wine must be fruity and a little bit acid. Usually they have malic acid, tartaric acid and citric acid. They play a fundamental role in avoiding the "splitting" of the cheese fondue: when the droplets of fat don't mix with the proteines you get a mass of cheese floating on oil. All the acids help split the proteins molecules and facilitate the emulsion with fat.   
So if you add lemon juice you just add an insurance against the fondue "splitting". If you have a good wine like fendant then you don't need it. It's you last resort in an emergency case.

you can get all the info on brewing online, there is a plethora of info out there.    
for basic, simple brews the set up is cheap. a plastic bucket kit with all you need to make 10L to 20L for around 70- 100 CHF. its super easy, pay attention to hygiene & follow instructions (yeah tough for us males) and you have pretty good beer in 4 to 8 weeks. Ingredient kits then cost 15 to 25 chf... just add water & sugar.    
if you have a decent size kettle (10L or bigger) you can then move to 'partial mash' where you steep grains (like making tea) and then add extract / hops. this can produce beer at evens or better than the craft beers we pay 3/4/5/6+ CHF for...    
if your prepared to spend a little more $$ you can move to all grain. Its actually simple & once you outlay the set up (large kettle & probably need an outdoor gas burner) the brews are cheap. Amarillo pale Ale i made on the weekend cost 20CHF for 21L.    
have a google of brew in a bag, or BIAB .. super simple.

A couple of years ago, we made two batches, using the same Yorkshire Sloes.   
First batch was done the traditional way, where you prick the sloes individually with a pin. This a) takes bloody ages; b) stains your fingers semi-permanently the colour of an uncooked lobster's shell; and c) eventually leads you to prick said blue fingers instead of expected blue sloes - causing swearing, bleeding and searching for plasters. (Drinking spare gin while doing the preparation may not have helped here).   
The second lot we followed the recipe from BBC Good Food programme on't wireless. Mainly because I got so annoyed with pricking (and ran out of gin), leading me to Freeze the rest.   
When solid (about a week) drop the bags of sloes once on a hard floor from about 4ft up to shatter some, put in mixing pan, pour over with gin. They will crack and split impressively. Add sugar, wait, strain and bottle as all other recipes.   
We left these both to mature same amount of time (over a year) and WOW - what a difference. Frozen version was darker, sweeter, more berry flavours ; so much better. Pinned version was a sherry red (not a typo) and sharper.   
Freeze it. Easier, better, and more convenient.   
Regards     
Ian

The best veggie options that I've found in a close proximity to each other, are around Limmatplatz. I believe that's only one bus ride away from you, so worth the effort. You've got India Supermarkt Maharajah just off Langstrasse on Josefstrasse, Denner is opposite that, and the Migros on Limmatplatz has one of the most diverse selections of veggie food. And if that's not enough, you've also got SamSeS vegetarian buffet restaurant across the road from the Denner en route to Migros.         
There's also an Asian store inside Hauptbahnhof by the Sihlquai entrance, opposite Burger King. From inside the station, just take the  escalators from the 'D' section of platforms 41, 42, 43 or 44 instead of the ones that lead up to the main station concourse / Shopville.

I like to try new things, go to restaurants and cook by myself. My last "discovery" were "kochboxen".  
Kochbox is a bag or a box with cooking recepe and ingredients (vegetables, meat, fish,  herbals, etc). All is measured according to the recepe. 
What is the advantage? You don't need to go to the shop and you have a possibility to learn to cook a new dish.   
I tried kochbox from HelloFresh.ch and kochbox from Leibgericht.ch  
My experience: ingredients and recepies in both cases were good. 
What might be a benefit in HelloFresh.ch is that they can deliver in the morning and during the day, and leibgericht.ch only in the evening.   
What I really liked by Leibgericht.ch is that on their site you can choose what you want to cook (and with HelloFresh you get a fixed box of 3 dishes).   
The price also differs a lot.  To try 3 dishes of HelloFresh for CHF115 (trial box) from my point of view is exaggerated. 
For around CHF 100 I ordered  5 dinners for 2 people in Leibgericht.   
Who else has an experience with Kochboxen? Let's share!

post:
I am chewing this very moment on a slice.    
400 grammes Halbweissmehl 
100 grammes Rye flour 
150 grammes Sour dough starter 
If I am cheating or in a hurry a small lump of yeast dissolved in water 
Salt A good teaspoon full   
Everything in a food processor,with enough water to make it good and sticky.Into a bowl to rise for a couple of hours. 
Then in a colander lined with a well floured cloth till it doubles in size.   
Oven on full belt with a cast iron casserole in it. When the max. temp. is reached take the casserole out and tip the dough in. Lid on and on the bottom shelf for 20 minutes. Lid off and another 20 minutes. I use the starter that is left over from the missuses dough recipe. She got it out of Annabell. It tastes better but takes about three days to make.

30 years, correct. Even if half has decayed there are areas where the ionizing radiation in mushrooms is still in the regions of "thousands of Becquerel" Foods with over 600 Becquerel are not allowed to be sold.   
(from Bundesamt für Strahlung, Germany) 
Bestimmte Pilzarten und Wildarten sind in einigen Gegenden  Deutschlands durch die Reaktorkatastrophe von Tschernobyl noch immer  stark mit    belastet. Der Süden Deutschlands  vor allem Südbayern und der  Bayerische Wald  sind davon besonders betroffen. In den letzten Jahren  (2011 bis 2015) wurden Werte von bis zu mehreren Tausend   pro Kilogramm bei Wild und bei bestimmten Speisepilzen gemessen. 
In Deutschland ist es nicht erlaubt, Lebensmittel mit einem Radiocäsiumgehalt von mehr als 600   pro Kilogramm in den Handel zu bringen. Für den Eigenverzehr gilt diese Beschränkung nicht. 
  Wenn Wildbret oder wild wachsende Speisepilze in üblichen Mengen  verzehrt werden, ist die zusätzliche Strahlenbelastung zwar  vergleichsweise gering, aber vermeidbar. Wer seine persönliche Belastung  verringern möchte, sollte in den höher belasteten Gebieten Deutschlands  auf den Genuss selbst erlegten Wildes und selbst gesammelter Pilze  verzichten.   
What I am saying is just be careful and don´t eat too many.

You know, I find it always a part of the initiation process when getting to know a new employee / Manager.  When knowing that my origins are from the U.K., one of the first informal questions is always about my tea consumption  .   
I never drink tea unless seriously ill (although my Swiss daughter loves it, and so we have all the necessary plants / boxes of fresh herbs), but I never divulge this.     
So, after discussing the coffee variation I usually have to point out that I also drink only Nescafe, despite having the latest designer Italian dispenser in my kitchen - well, to be more accurate it's in my attic - because it requires too much effort in the morning as well as takes up too much space in the kitchen despite looking cool.   
I know that this is a no-go, but the caffeine simply keeps me awake the whole night and I can't see the point  .

For me the go-to site for more or less local recipes is chefkoch.de.   
An extra simple example: 
500g Spätzli (Chnöpfli in swiss German)  
3-400g Sauerkraut (white, sweet) 
100-150g dairy butter   
Prepare Sauerkraut and Spätzli as prescribed on its respective package,  let any liquid drip off the Sauerkraut (if applicable) and heat it in  the microwave if necessary. Melt the butter in a pan, high-ish heat so  it turns a nice golden (perhaps a bit brown) color (too much heat if it "smokes") and  pour over the Sauerkraut/Spätzli mixture. Done, serve.   
I love bread to go along with this. You can add roasted onion/ham and a lot of other stuff, but I prefer this very basic make.

I figured I'd try here before I head to Ricardo and overpay. (I'm in the ZH area, work in Oerlikon,live in the Unterland)   
Thanks!

Step 1. Go to Coop 
Step 2. Buy the pork loin or two 
Step 3. Go to asian food store off Langstrasse or in HB

Step 4. Go home and marinade the bastard  (add a bit of 5 spice for flavour) 
Step 5. Cook in oven with the grill setting 
Step 6. Eat, actually tastes better the next day.   
Your welcome

I am aware of several millions British people who regard the cuisine from "Greater India" as their own cuisine. But not only are there some other 10s of millions of Brits who do not feel thelike, there also are several 100s million people on the Indian subcontinent who will not accept that their cuisine is "British cuisine". This in spite of the apparent fact that a good part of all gastronomy folk in Britain of Paki-Indian-etc origin have obtained British citizenship.    
The woman of the "Chef" of the oldest Indian restaurant in Zürich (Raja Bongo Restaurant) is of Swiss origin, but is doing more of the cooking than her husband. Indian cuisine already in the late 1970ies became a heavy part of her life.    
Many Swiss regard Spaghetti, Salami, Tagliatelle etc as "their" cuisine, but not even Italians with Swiss citizenship would ever describe Italian cuisine as "Swiss cuisine". There are uncountable Swiss native German speakers and French speakers successfully active in Italian cuisine, but it for them still is, in a way not THEIR but ANOTHER cuisine, in spite of Swiss Cuisine having taken over Spaghetti and Salami etc long ago. True, the TICINO is a kind of "Knautschzone"/"gears-synchronisation-tool" between Italy and Switzerland which makes it easier

We don't slice our raclette cheese, we grate it like roesti instead as that makes it much easier to use the amount of cheese the individual prefers.   
To freeze the grated cheese we use ordinary zippable plastic bags that are laid flat in the freezer with the cheese loosely-packed and no more than perhaps 1.5-2cm thick. If we manage to remember we shake the bags once they're half-frozen, again laying them flat. That enables you to break off any portion if you don't need to thaw up the full contents.

Some restaurant markups are ridiculous (Park Hyatt Zürich charging 4x retail making a 100 CHF wine 400 CHF) and are completely unfair in that they penalise people wanting to drink high quality wines. There are however a few places where the markups are more than fair and you feel happy about ordering something good off the card. The Carlton restaurant and James Joyce pub offer well selected wines at really fair prices in downtown Zürich. The Carlton is a bit more fancy (though the food is great and fairly priced) and James Joyce is great for a burger, actually good fish & chips, and perhaps the best club sandwich in Zürich. It takes a bit of research in Switzerland but fair priced booze does exist!

They are really not difficult to make. Here's the recipe I make:       
For suet, place a stick of butter in the deep freeze and grate it into the mix in place of the suet. Treacle you can get at Globus and Jelmoli. If you own a pressure cooker, you can cook it by steaming with pressure off for 30 mins, then at 5lb pressure for about 2 to 2.5 hours. Pour a tablepoon of brandy over the cooled pudding then store, covered with greaseproof and foil in a dark cupboard for upto a month.

To the OP, aren't you the one who has a Swiss boyfriend and you tried to live here once, moved back to the US and are now here again to make a fresh start?   
If so, yearning for obscure things like root beer is not the way to go.  If you really are serious about assimilating this time, learn to drink Rivella, be happy with Coke or start drinking wine like the rest of us.   
Did you not learn your lesson the first time?  Find alternatives for your big, cheap bottles of Tylenol, full-strength bleach, brown sugar and deodorant soap.  (And root beer.)  Love your boyfriend, learn his language, embrace his country and his culture and move on.  You can still be American, but you don't have to so blatantly act like such a stereotype.  It gives the rest of us, (and there aren't many left of us, quite frankly), a bad name.

Just before you enter the tunnel leading to the border crossing, turn right at the light. Keep going straight for about 5 minutes and the first roundabout turn left again ( enter at 6 exit at 9 ). 
You will then enter France through an unmanned border crossing called "douane de Vireloup" go straight and you will end up in the center of Ferney-Voltaire (Carrefour will be to your left), thus avoiding the lines at Ferney border crossing.   
Take the same route when you come back, the 5 min drive is a lot more pleasant than sitting in traffic.

As a serious Roast Beef fan (when I'm in London I never miss visiting Hix's Oyster and Chop House) I must disagree with the suggestions hitherto made, much as they   make a nice beef meal.   
I've found that the closest you can get in Switzerland to a proper English standing Rib Roast is the Côte de Boeuf. BUT it has to be at least a kilo or two in weight. A teeny tiny Côte de Boeuf will not really give you a decent Roast Beef Experience. Although monstrously expensive, a large, aged (at least 28 days) Côte de Boeuf makes for a great dinner party dish plus provide leftovers for all kinds of things (such as thin sliced, on white, with mayo, English mustard and a good sprinkling of salt and pepper).   
Finally, is it me, or do others EFers find that the Swiss butchers remove so much fat, and the meat is not marbled  , so that unless you can afford a thick steak to flash grill you are doomed to dry meat (even if cooked pink)???

post:
how about       
?

My hubby makes his own BM.  
He makes a big bowl full that sits in the fridge and keeps us going for most of the week. it doesn't need to be fresh everyday, it improves with age    
Into a 2 liter bowl grate 1 apple (unpeeled) we prefer Braeburn. 
Then add 2 large handfuls of Migros   Reddy Birchermuesli Berries mix and stir into the apple. 
Next throw in some sultanas - only if you like them  
Next add 1 large tub 500g of Migros mixed berry or other flavour - stir again. 
Then put a mug full of [still] frozen mixed forest berries - stir again and then add enough milk to make it quite a sloppy mixture - it will thicken a lot overnight. This part needs and a bit of experimentation and tinkering to personal taste.   
Cover and put in the fridge overnight.  
The next day to will be very thick or solid and this is the time to add more milk/yogurt/orange juice (if you like it less sweet) to loosen it up, give it a good stir. 
Scoop into a bowl and enjoy!!   
The remainder will last 4-5 days in the fridge, but it wont thicken any more.   
GT

Val-de-Travers absinthe comes in very many guises, from very many distillers- and with a great variety of plant mixes and also alcohol strengths- including some (natural) greens drunk with spoon and sugar ('blanches' also known as 'bleues' due to the blueish tinge when it is 'louched' with water are drunk without sugar just very cold water- from a wooden fountain up in a dale in the woods even better) - and of course the strength can be diluted with more water rather than less. We usually drink it with 2.5 to 3 parts of water- as the herbs and flavours come out much better with more, rather than less, water. Come over one day Wooli and I'll take you to all the best distillers here.   
But yes, some Rakis are really good- much better than the much too sweet Ouzos and Pastis (Pastis Pernod was invented in Pontarlier after absinthe was banned) - we had a representative from Pernod last night at our international outing, as they have reintroduced absinthes in their range- sadly not always sucessfully. They presented us with cocktails which were quite nice- but give me simple V-d-T absinthe anytime!

What pisses me -- an American -- off about the American government's foreign food factory inspections is that while foreign factories are required to meet capricious standards, lest they be cut off from the huge American market, domestic food plants are not held to the same standards. Well, technically they are, but on American soil, the sanctions the government can take are incredibly ineffective.   
So the end result is bullsh!t like not being able to import wonderful European dry hams (prosciutto, Schwarzwälderschinken, jamon iberico, etc) because their factories -- while seemingly adequate as to not poison all of Europe and Asia -- don't meet USDA standards, while domestic American meatpacking plants that ship out millions of pounds of bacterially contaminated ground beef receive a slap on the wrist, but cannot be shut down with anything even remotely describable as "expediency". (It was only recently that one Spanish jamon iberico producer went through all the red tape to build a USDA-approved plant, finally allowing Americans to taste what I consider to be the finest ham in the world.)    
FYI, in USA, regulatory authority over the food supply is divided between the FDA and USDA, depending on what it is and whether it's processed or not, so both can and do conduct inspections domestically and abroad.

Hi all,   
I just discovered a coffee shop in Schwamendingen! I think it opened in June. It's called Coffee & Deeds.        
It is a cute space and the coffees/teas are reasonably priced. They have a lovely outdoor seating area and an activity box for kids. The service is really friendly and they try to source locally.    
This coffee shop is some sort of initiative from the local reformed church. I do like the idea of buying an anonymous coffee for someone who might not be having the best of times (unemployed, etc.).   
I think it's a great little place and reminds me of the shop I used to frequent in San Francisco.

Both PG Tips and Brooke Bond are OK english teas but if you want to go up a rung in taste and quality you should try Yorkshire Tea which is available online from Britshop.   
If you want to take the experience to a higher level and like a full-blooded malty tea, then the best in my experience is Barry's tea. Naturally, leaves are the best but it's also available in bags directly from their store in Ireland. Shipment is very fast and they don't rip you off with the postage.
Why not Ragusa ? It tastes very good. I personally wouldn't take Frey, for me it lacks personality.

The fresher the egg, the more difficult it is to shell after hard-boiling.  The trick to nice hard-boiled eggs is to store them at home for a week before attempting to hard boil them.  Plunging them into cold water after boiling stops the yolk going grey, it has no effect on the ease of peeling.     
The good news is that if you think Swiss eggs are difficult to peel after boiling, it only demonstrates that they are fresher than what you're used to.

An easy and quick favourite of mine is salad with cervelat and Appenzell cheese. Very tasty!       
You'll need:    
1. 4 Cervelat sausages 
2. 1 tsp mild mustard  
3. herb vinegar: amount based on personal preference but generally 3 tbsp 
4. 1 tbsp mayo 
5. finely chopped chives  
6. Appenzell cheese (or your fav cheese - I sometimes use grumpygrapefruits' English cheese  ) 
7. small onion sliced into rings: skip this step if you arent really into onions 
8. 2 hardboiled eggs 
9. 4 tbsp Rapeseed or sunflower oil (I personally use olive oil)   
a. Remove skin of cervelat sausages and slice  
b. mix with salad, salt, pepper and eggs!   
Tadaaa!   
PS: gherkins are optional too.

post:
I had the same query when I first got my gas grill; how much gas is left in the bottle and is it enough for the next grilling session. So after looking around on the net, I found that a really simple method to roughly gauge how much is left in the bottle is to pour warm water down the side of it and run your hand down from the top to the bottom and you will feel the temperature difference.  
The propane absorbs the heat from the warm water and so you will immediately feel the coldness and know if you have gas in there or not.    
For a much more accurate way of knowing how much is in there and if you have enough left for your next grill session, you can use  .  
I found that after a while, I got to know by feel if there was enough for my cooking or not. 
I think if you are using your grill a lot, it would be worth it to invest in a second tank as there will be no scrambling mid-cook  and also, you will take an empty tank back to replace, not an almost empty one that you don't know if it's going to be enough or not one, I mean, it's just giving money away and I always say, "it's better in my pocket than theirs". 
Happy grilling   
Edit, if I had a spare bottle, I would keep it in an out of the way place close to the grill if possible, so if you need to swap it mid cook your heat loss is minimal. They are very safe, truly...

Hello everyone!   
As the temperatures rise in the summer (not today, though...), I would like to share the recipe of a vinegar salad typically eaten at barbecues in Brazil. Meat lovers eat it with meat, vegetarians eat it with bread...   
I hope you like it!   
Recipe:   
Cut tomatoes (2 or 3), onions (1), cucumbers (1), you can also add bell peppers (1) if you like. (The numbers give you more or less the proportions.)   
Chopped parsley and green onions can also be nice (I sometimes just use Schnittlauch instead of green onions).   
Some people like to cut a little bit of chili peppers (I maybe would put a half of a small one.)   
I like to either fry (in a bit olive oil) or boil the onions, so they are not so strong. If you like raw onions a lot, then you do not need to do that.   
Then you mix everything in a bowl and you must taste all the time until you get it spiced as you like   
I add one soup spoon of vinegar. Then I gradually add sugar. Unfortunately I can't tell you how much sugar because it really depends, but I can tell you that one soup spoon of sugar could be a start. When you taste it and if you like the sweetness, you start adding salt, maybe with as little as a very small spoon (tea spoon).   
Remember that it takes a bit time to get the sense of sugar and salt, so the ideal is to put some, go away for a few minutes, come back and taste, put more, etc... I feel that within a few minutes the taste "grows."   
I also add a bit of olive oil at the end.   
You can also substitute the vinegar for lemon juice. It also tastes nice!   
Let me know how it came out!

post: Meat hostage sharing, helping hands to carry large purchases. People like me with a Mercedes Vito, 3 seats, huge carry area, I can only bring 300euro of stuff. So we write an EFShopper app. GPS tracks us when we are over the border, we phone scan our purchases as we walk in the shop, if a different person has an item in their basket that day costing less in a different store, one shopper is prompted to put theirs back, the other efshopper takes two! EFers can log on as daytripper (Potential Meat hostage), shopper, or shopper with car. We can meet up for socials, resync/optimise goods, have language classes, social events in a reasonably priced bars, etc. We can have WTB lists, price flashes for spectacular reductions, pooling of discount cards, vouchers, etc. The list goes on and on!!!

post:
I think what may come closest to Weissmaisdunst is Rheintaler Ribelmais, available at major Coops and Migros. It is finer than polenta maize and much more whitish but substantially coarser than corn starch.    
Ribel is a very traditional meal in the St. Galler part of the Rhine valley, originally a poor people's staple but now experiencing a revival not only among new-age grain-peckers and gluten avoiders.    
Bramata is the yellow variant used in the Grisons, and coarser than Ribelmais too; no substitute for Weissmaisdunst.

Most of us foragers and gatherers learnt as babe in arms, with our parents- so it comes very naturally. The leaves of lilly of the valley are indeed similar from a distance, and poisonous- but once you know the difference, you just cannot ever get it wrong. Wild garlic leaves are much softer, the flower is totally different- but mostly the very strong garlic smell is the key- lilly of the valley leaves do not smell at all.   
And of course us foragers and gatherers also have many books to check, cross reference, etc. The first rule you learn is that if you are not sure, don't pick- leave well alone. Most of us also know the medicinal use of herbs and plants- and cross-check with many books and on-line sources.   
Ecchinococosis is indeed a problem, mainly in the East and central Switzerland (I live in the Far West). I pick wild strawberries in our garden- as they grow everywhere- but in the wild I stick to raspberries and blackberries which grow higher up. Sadly, the larvae are not killed by washing or freezing- so there is always a risk. Cooking does kill them- so making jam or soups, etc, is totally fine.   
However, foxes are everywhere- and can access market gardens or commercial growing land too- so are you going to stop eating all raw food?   
Personally I am much more scared about 'clean' dirt- pesticides, herbicides, etc- on my food, truly.

By Elvis Ocakbasi Restaurant : the food is tasty and service is the best.  As many other Turkish restaurants, the owner used to run a little kebab imbiss, then turned to a restaurant but the managing quality is still in imbiss standarts. weird decoration, loud music, mix of traditional and modern but not in a cool way.     
01ocakbasi: it is the last stop of tram 17. i have been there 2-3 times. food is ok, service is terrible , decoration is same like elvis style. i don t like there, but there are many who loves it.   
Bodrum: the name comes from Bodrum which is the most popular touristic town in Turkey. it used to be a small fisherman village in 70s. and this restaurant reminds me that Bodrum in 70s. Plastic table chair sets outside, simple food, slow but friendly service. I like the atmosphere but for it is not a place for everyone.   
cafe ferdinand: as mentioned in a previous thread, it runs as a italian cafe during the day and a turkish restaurant in the evenings  it is homemade traditonal turkish food like manti , dolma, zeytinyagli fasulye..ec. no kebab or such.    
valentins: the owner of bodrum restaurant and valentins are same. it is a family restaurant. the food is good, they don t have doener kebab but have similar stuff..(iskender, ali nazik..etc) service is friendly, prices are not cheap, decoration is the best compared to others.   
Bebek: it was the most trendy bar of 2014 summer and still it is very popular. the owners are swiss and the restaurant /cafe is inspired from the Bebek district of Istanbul. the menu is full with  turkish meze style food.  They have cocktails named as Gezi park, Mersini ..etc. As I remember in the menu there was ; borek, cacik, musakka, muammara, hellim kizartma, mercimek corba, kisir, ezme.. Service is great, ambience is number one. In the end it is not a Turkish restaurant and food is updated for Europeans ( no salca, or not too spicy) but still it my number 1 stop to have Turkish food

post:
Yup, we make it right in the pan with the sausage. Slice some onions into thin slices. Half a small white onion should do for 2 people.   
When the sausage is about 5 mins from done, drop a small knob of butter into the pan away from the sausage. Once it's bubbly, add the onions and let them soften and brown, stirring regularly with a wooden spoon. Add a little bit of white wine on them if they look dry. Don't worry if they mix a bit with the sausage. Again, we cook this covered, not open.   
Remove sausage from pan when it's done. While it's resting, quickly finish the sauce. Turn up the heat and add a little bit of flour to the onion-wine mix. Stir to incorporate (kind of like making a roux) and then add more wine to make the sauce. Stir constantly so it isn't gummy! Add a bit of salt and fresh-grated pepper. If you don't want to use wine, bouillon works too (we use veggie stock sometimes).   
HTH

Having tried mexican food all over switzerland, using some of the reviews of this forum as a guide, i am quite impressed by the food at Comelon burrito bar.   
The owners run a tortilla company that sells to Manor and perhaps some other places and they finally opened a small storefront in the old town in Vevey, just off the marche.       
(they seem to have more info on their facebook page)   
Prices are reasonable for switzerland (CHF 13.50/burrito, CHF 18 meal with chips and drink, or 9 to 11 for a quesadilla +4.5 for meal combo).    
Mexico is a a big place with all kinds of regional food variations, and mexican food in the US has all sorts of different regional variations as well, but to me the flavors, concept and price of this place are really good and worth a try - especially after trying place after place over the past few years and being very disappointed.  There are definitely aspects that aren't "authentic" but in the same way that a chipotle burrito isn't authentic either, but still tastes good (to me).   
It has a similar vibe to burrito brothers or amigo taco in lausanne, but has more seating.   
some downsides are the lunch only hours, potential for long lines at peak lunch time, limited menu and seating.

If any of you have recipes eg.   that require a deep dish pie plate you will know that they are relatively difficult to find in CH.    
The typical CH glass pie plate is about 29-30 cm in diameter and 3.5 cm high. Great for certain tartes but not good for anything that has more volume.   
TopTip (Coop group) is currently selling a set of 2 glass pie plates (reg. CHF 24.90 for CHF 12.90). The one that is most interesting is the larger one that is 30 cm diameter and  (measured at the rim). The brand is borcam. The smaller pie plate is 24 cm in diameter and 4.5 cm at the rim.   
Their code for the product (if you don't see it) is 4.696.629

Rote Fabrik - average and overrated place, quite far from anywhere else, and very crappy service. Much better in Summer 
El Lokal - good, as suggested 
Rimini, on the river Sihl - not even open now... so pointless suggestion 
Hafenkneipe - Nothing special, but has live music occasionally... 
Schiffbau, has a bar on top - average, and layout not good for people watching. 
this is seasonal but should have winter bar:   - (Summer place)   
- Edis Weinstube for inexpensive wine and a laid-back atmosphere for chatting. 
- Paddy Reilly's on a Friday/Saturday night- usually charts music and a lot of people chatting and dancing. 
- Clouds at the Prime Tower, if you want to try some unique cocktails and enjoy a great view of the city.  
- Jules Verne bar is nice for this also... 
- Barflyz in Enge is another nice place for a chat, with good prices. 
- Meyers in Wiedikon is open late, and a fun dive bar. 
- Old Crow has a nice atmosphere and an excellent beverage selection. 
- Purpur and Carlton are both nice, but a little pricey for what you get (esp Carlton with their Tuesday afterwork ripoff).   
I've been in Mascotte, and a few other paid-entry clubs, and they generally get too crowded for me.   
El Toro Bar in Langstrasse- for Latin music.   
In the Langstasse area: 
- Bar 3000 (small but trendy) 
- Mata Hari (fun tiki bar) 
- Ole Ole Ole (bring coins for the Juke Box!) 
- Acapulco (karaoke every Sunday) 
- Casablanca (quieter vibe) 
- George not off langstrasse but also not too far (retro rooftop bar)

Templeton is a good one too, but my education in ryes was done in the U.S. where a large selection is very accessible so I quickly started to categorize and rate whiskies...especially by value.   
I found Templeton to be very agreeable, but at 35 USD, it couldn't stand a chance against a 20 USD Rittenhouse. Bulleit was also a staple of mine. They make a great bourbon at a decent price. Since you like Bulleit Rye, try Knob Creek's for a few dollars more; it is now one of my favourite special evening drinks. It is not twice as good as Rittenhouse, but it has more interesting flavors and is less fiery. I drink it on the rocks, while Rittenhouse makes the perfect mixing rye for Manhattans. Also if you get a chance, try the Thomas H. Handy...it's 135 proof but sublime!   
Speaking of which, I recently tried Cocchi's sweet vermouth. It's a very fine contender for the #1 spot which is currently held by Carpano Antico. I'm coming to terms with the fact that a Manhattan pretty much knocks me out by 20:30. If I drink just the rye I have no drowsiness. So I too am moving toward drinking just single liquors. I'm also a fan of Monkey 37 Gin made in Germany. It's excellent neat but also in a G&T.

The market for white truffles is not easy, most restaurants buy only from their usual supplier, because the product is really expensive and guests expect high quality because of the price. 
The demand is not very high, even in zurich. 
Most restaurants have only truffles on special occasions, because the truffels loose weight (white truffles around 10 % in 3 Days ), so if you can't sell it in 3 days , you will loose a lot of money.

It works on the basis that different parts of the meat transform at different temperatures -- hence, you can make a totally succulent, entirely medium rare steak with no risk of overcooking by holding it at a constant 55C until the entire piece of meat reaches that temperature.  Because you don't exceed that temperature, the meat does not cook beyond the desired point.   
You then finish it over a very high heat to seal in all of the Maillard-reaction yumminess.   
Chances are, if you've had a steak in a decent steakhouse in the past five years, you've had a sous-vide steak.  Sous-vide means that even the most hung-over line chef can turn out consistent steak after steak, each cooked to perfection.

Same with flour - it's quite possible to fill a container, then knock it down and fit more in.    
And of course using proper metric measures means that even water quantities that we do measure by volume means you can still weigh them without any conversion needed (1ml=1g).

Making a brine measuring salt by volume is bound to fail as the amount will heavily depend on grain size.    
I used a 5% solution, where half of the liquid was vinegar (mixture of 2/3 wine and 1/3 apple cider). 
I added bay leaf, mustard seeds, coriander seeds, garlic, fresh dill.   
During the so called Sauregurkenzeit (July-August), you can get cucumbers, flowering dill, jars, and a big variety of vinegar at any German supermarket.

I made mutter paneer bhurji last night using Coop paneer.   
I made 2 observations:   
- I found it a tad salty as compared to the paneer I'm normally used to. When making a dish with it, take this into account and reduce the amount of salt you add to the recipe.   
- I also found the texture similar to a semi hard cheese (Asiago/Provolone/Emmental). I'm normally used to a more crumbly textured younger paneer, rather than semi-hard/stretchy.   
It worked great in the recipe because I adjusted the level of salt, grated it and cooked it for a very short time. But there is a difference.   
In terms of convenience and not having to go into the city to an Indian shop, it's brilliant. Fortunately my local Denner is now selling paneer from a local farm and I'm really looking forward to trying that out.   
p.s. I am aware that asiago/provolone/Emmental varies depending on how long it's matured, I'm talking about the semi hard kind which I think is matured 2-3 months.

What can I say?  I'm impatient.   
Instead of waiting for a review, we headed down to the restaurant at lunchtime today and were pleasantly surprised with the results.  Yeah, the place is never going to win awards for its authentic Japanese menu (it's the standard French-Japanese formula of set menus with sushi, sashimi, gyoza and yakatori in various combinations that you find in every Japanese restaurant in France), but they've not done badly.   
The interior decoration is nice enough and the place has obvious just been redone.  It's nicer inside than it looks from the street.   
The various combos cost between EUR14 for the smaller ones to EUR20 for the bigger ones.  We ordered the big sharing combo ("on veut un bateau, svp!") with soup, salad, 8 nigiri, 12 maki, and 24 slices of sashimi for EUR48.   
Notably, the quality of the rolled sushi and freshness of the fish are much better than Fuji sushi (at the other end of Saint Louis).     
My colleague and I went in with low expectations, but they turned out to be unfounded -- the place is pretty good!  If you haven't tried this place yet and need a reasonably-priced sushi fix, give it a go.

If I'm in the vicinity, I'll stop by for a quick bite. Unfortunately I find their food just ok, nothing outstanding. I find it very strange that they use Thai sriracha as their chilli sauce. It puts me off to be honest. While I love sriracha, why serve it with Lebanese cuisine? It just doesn't seem right to me...And yes, chilli is extremely important to me!      Delices d'orient is a place I frequent often. I love the food there.  A couple of times, as soon as I walked in the door, they offered me a free hot crispy fried falafel as a sample. Great hospitality!    
It's a tiny spot with a couple of stools, and as long as you go during meal times, the food is fresh, delicious and inviting. I've also once been in the middle of the afternoon but I was unfortunately served 'warm drawer dried out chicken' shawarma.    
I often have their kafta teller consisting of a fantastic range of mezze on one plate with 2 large kaftas and a piece of durum/fladenbrot. Plus he makes his own chilli sauce  .   
Noonbar I have yet to try, looking forward to it...

We are from India, and have not been too experimental in our cooking - we usually stick to Indian masalas and spices; the only non-Indian pantry supplies we buy have been restricted to: 
A variety of herbs 
Cheese (mostly brie, gouda, feta, parmesan) 
Vinegars (rice, balsamic, chilli, apple cider) 
Sauces (soy, tomato, fish sauce, sweet and sour, teriyaki, barbeque) 
Olives 
EVOO   
With the above, I my weeknight meals range from Chinese, Thai, Italian, Mexican (aside from the obvious Indian).  
Recently, at a friend's place, I tried pasta with tinned sardines and I was blown away by the boost of flavor from these.    
I'd like to know what are your favourite pantry staples from local stores here - sweet/ savory doesn't matter - would love to try new and interesting flavors in our cooking. TIA!

Found a receipe in English for Pizokel:   
Pizokel with cabbage, Canton Graubünden (Bizoccals cun ravitscha)       Pizokel were eaten in a wide variety of ways. In some places when eaten by themselves they are known in Rumantsch as "bizochels bluts", or bald pizokel.    
If someone leaves a small amount of any kind of food on the serving dish for politeness sake, in the Engadine this is called "far sco quel dal bizoccal", meaning more or less leaving the last pizokel.       
Ingredients for the pizokel for four people:   
* 7 oz buckwheat flour 
* ¼ cup milk 
* 2 beaten eggs 
* ½ oz finely chopped Bündnerfleisch (air-dried beef) 
* ½ oz finely chopped Salsiz (spicy salami-type sausage) 
* ¾ oz finely chopped leek 
* 1 tsp butter 
* salt 
* nutmeg   
Ingredients for vegetable and bacon accompaniment:   
* 2 oz bacon strips 
* 1 pinch garlic 
* ½ oz finely chopped onion 
* 1 tsp butter 
* 4 oz Savoy cabbage 
* 4 oz spinach 
* salt 
* pepper 
* nutmeg 
* ¼ cup whipping cream   
For the pizokel:   
1. Put the flour, milk and eggs into a bowl and stir to obtain a smooth dough 
2. Braise Bündnerfleisch, Salsiz and leek in the butter, then mix into the dough. 
3. Spread the soft dough thinly over a clean surface, using your hands. (It will be too soft use a rolling pin.) 
4. Cut into strips about 2 inches long, and drop into boiling water. 
5. When they rise to the surface, fish them out with a slotted spoon.   
For the accompaniment:   
1. Cut cabbage and large spinach leaves into large pieces, but leaving no leaves whole, and cook briefly in salted water.  
2. Drain well. Braise bacon strips, garlic and onion in the butter, add vegetable mixture. 
3. Add drained pizokel. Season to taste with salt, pepper and nutmeg. 
4. Stir in cream and serve immdiately

When I buy mine fresh, I store them (on the fridge's veg shelf) on a large platter next to each other, leaving gaps between the berries, as opposed to keeping them all smushed together in their teeny box. This way, sorting out the bad ones is easier and they tend to stay fresh longer.   
Another important thing is to leave the green stems/leaves on because cutting them off a long time before use will lessen the berry flavor and give bugs etc. a way to get inside.

I don't believe in Pharmaceuticals. They give you temporary relief, if they work.   
If I start to get sniffles, which is rare, I delve into my supply of dried nettles and locally bought honey and make a tea.   
If I don't have any dried nettles, I'll nip into the nearby woods and pick some wild nettles, given the right time of year.   
Nettle contains a natural histamine and clears up any sniffles I have, if ever.   
I also add peppermint to the brew.   
Works for me!

post:
I think it is real but a very exaggerated condition. Part of the problem is that the wheat we eat has changed dramatically since humans first started harvesting & grinding plants into flour to make bread. Old style wheat looks nothing like what we see growing today, old style wheat is about 3 times the height for one. Also given that bread, cakes etc are normally made of a highly refined product that bears little resemblance to what our bodies were used to I'm not surprised that some people have problems with it. It can also be a problem of overloading, wheat based cereal for breakfast, sandwich for lunch & pasta for evening meal; that is not balanced. Too much of any one food is going to leave you feeling crap whether that is apples or bread.    
Personally I avoid too much wheat/gluten, if I have too much my stomach bloats and feels very uncomfortable therefore I try to avoid it by eating a varied diet and using other forms of grain for my carb intake. If someone gives me a sandwich or cooks me pasta I will happily eat it though. Too many people use it as an excuse to not eat certain food.

Here's a list of Super foods:   
Bacon sandwich 
Fried chicken 
Chocolate mousse 
Creme Brulee 
Thai green curry

I make my own hummus:   
Ingredients 
200g canned chickpeas 
2 tbsp lemon juice or more 
2 garlic cloves, crushed 
1 tsp ground cumin 
Salt 
3 tbsp tahini (sesame seed paste) 
4 tbsp water 
2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil 
1 tsp paprika   
Preparation method: 
Drain the chickpeas and rinse. 
Combine the chickpeas, lemon juice, garlic, cumin, salt, tahini, and water in a food processor, and blend to a creamy purée. 
Add more lemon juice, garlic, cumin or salt to taste. Drizzle with extra virgin olive oil. Store in the fridge.   
You can also substitute half the chickpeas with a small boiled beetroot for a lovely earthy flavour.

I'm sorry but this is really not true. I've eaten Wagyu (Kobe) on a number of occasions and you can't eat it rare. Kobe is prized because of the tightly packed marbling and this marbling needs to have time to render all the way through in order to get the delicate, almost gelatinous texture Kobe-eaters are after. Kobe needs to be cooked to a minimum of medium rare and probably medium to soften the fat all the way through.

Since being here I have sought out this option numerous times, and since have a couple of personal options I can use. But I was thinking, since I had such a hard time finding the real thing, could others be interested in renting my tap system for parties and etc? I have a professional, mobile beer tap system that works for kegs with CO2 cannisters. It's always too expensive to have to rent the tap, then buy an entire keg, and the C02, plus the depos on all of these.      
So I was thinking, is there any interest, from say people on this forum to rent a tap system, where they paid a fee for the tap/Co2, the weight of beer used, and be done with it(putting a deposit down on the system as well of course, for parties, events, etc?      
I know from experience, if you try to arrange all this stuff on your own, the cost of beer is far more expensive then just buying bottles and putting them on ice. But, under my idea, it would either less expensive or on par, but it's always more kool to have your own tap. I tried to make this into a survey, but I don't see how to make that part of this thread work.     
So, is, there any interest? And if there is an interest, any suggestions on what a fair price would be for a service like this would be? Without working out details yet like, who picks it up, should it be delivered, and so on. Thanks.

Actually there's no real evidence that we evolved with any particular diet as a target. Quite the opposite, in fact, which is why we succeeded so well. If we live in times and places of plenty we can eat meat three times a day, with some vegetable intake as well, and survive perfectly well. In other times or places we can live on an entirely meat-free diet, albeit needing a lot more of it to survive.    
Being an Omnivore does not require that you eat all kinds of foods, just that you can if you want to.    
Personally I eat meat of some sort at least once a day, quite often more.

The problem is many apple juices contain pear juice - which below a certain percentage, doesn't even have to be declared on the labelling. This way producers can legitimately offload stocks of pears which can't be used for anything else.   
Often, it is the pear juice that produce the squits.

post: Shell-fish trawlers don't 'accidentally' catch skate or any other fish. They just take the destruction of all other marine life caught in their trawl nets into account. Once the 'fruits' of their labours have been sorted on board, the rest, and there can be quite a lot of it, - now dead - is simply heaved back into the sea. If it is taken 'home' it's used for animal feeds, mainly as cat food in tins or increasingly as fertiliser. More and more sea fish and shell fish are being farmed as there are no substainable fish at normal fishing depths. These fish are filled with nasty chemical things and live in each other's sh*t.

That said, I rarely use it any more. I've switched mostly to using "raw" black beans. I buy them in the yellow cardboard tube, this is what it looks like:      
They are much, much cheaper than the prepared sauce -- a 500g tube cost Fr. 3.50 at the Chinese shop!

Stick to fresh!

I know we can get very good bread here in Switzerland but I find there is no better smell than bread baking in the oven. The apartment smells wonderful for hours after and you save money at the same time, bliss.    
You will need:   
2 cups warm water. 
2 1/4 teaspoons dry yeast. 
1 tablespoon light brown sugar. 
5 - 5 3/4 cups bread flour 
1 tablespoon olive oil 
2 1/2 teaspoon salt 
1 egg white lightly beaten     
In a measuring jug, pour in 1/2 cup of the warm water. Stir in the yeast and sugar. Let it stand for 30 minutes until frothy. 
I find a lot of recipes say to leave the yeast and water mixture for a few minutes but in my experience I got better results when I left it longer and I found 30 minutes to be best.   
Combine 5 cups of the flour and the salt. Add the yeast mixture along with the remaining water and olive oil. Mix dough until it comes together.    
Transfer dough to a lightly floured surface and knead by hand until dough is smooth and firm. The dough should not be loose.   
Lightly spray a bowl with olive oil and lightly spray the dough also. Place dough in the bowl and cover with a damp tea towel. Leave in a warm draft free place for 2 hours until doubled in size.   
Preheat oven to 220 degrees c.   
Remove the risen dough from the bowl and punch down. Flatten the dough with the heel of your hand into a large rectangle. Roll the dough up tightly, sealing the seam well after each roll. The dough should be oval with a round end. Be sure the ends are well sealed also.   
Place dough on a floured board and baking sheet. Cover again with a tea towel  
And let rise for 1 hour.   
Brush dough with egg white and slash the bread down the middle.   
Bake for 40-45 minutes.

This perfect for valentines. I cooked this a few weeks ago and served it with home made garlic potato wedges and my husband raved about it. Enjoy x   
2 Sirlon steaks 
1 tablespoon olive oil 
2 tablespoons finely chopped shallot 
1\2 cup whiskey 
1cup chicken stock 
2 tablespoons whole grain mustard 
3 tablespoons unsalted butter 
1\2 teaspoon cider vinegar   
Pat dry steak and sprinkle with sat and pepper. 
Heat the oil in a pan over medium high heat until shimmering. Sear the steak turning once about 8 minutes for medium rare. Let steak stand uncovered for 10 minutes while you make the sauce.   
Add the shallots to the pan. Stir and cook until soft about 2 minutes. 
Add the whiskey and ignite using a long match. Be careful here I found the flames shoot right up. The flames will die down within a few seconds.  
When the flames die down add in the mustard, and stock. Bring the sauce to a boil and cook until reduced by half. About 6 minutes. Wisk in the meat juices, butter and vinegar and it is ready to serve.

post:
I baked these yesterday and my husband loved them. I hope you will like them too.   
1 pound/16 oz  plain flour 
4 oz butter softened 
One and a half tablespoons of sugar  
One and a half teaspoons of baking soda 
One teaspoon of salt 
Zest of one lemon 
Candied lemon pieces 
1 egg 
1 cup butter milk   
For the lemon drizzle 
1 cup powered sugar 
Juice of one lemon   
Preheat oven to 200 degrees C. 
Sift the butter, baking soda, salt and sugar I to a bowl. Rub in the butter using your first her tips until it is like sand.  
Stir in the candied lemon pieces. 
In another bowl whisk together the butter milk, egg and lemon peel. 
Make a well in the centre of the flour mix. Pour in the buttermilk mixture and using our hand bring everything together. It should be slightly sticky.  
Turn out the dough on a floured surface and form it in to a round shape. Don't over do the flour as this will change the recipe. The less handling the better it the more the dough is handled the less light and airy it will be. Using the plan of your hand flatten until it is one inch in height. 
Cut out the scones using a round cookie cutter or cut the flattened dough into 8ths. 
Place scones onto a prepared baking tray. I find it best to cover the tray with a sheet of baking parchment dusted with flour. 
Place the baking tray in the centre of the oven and bake for 17 mins if the scones are small or 20 mins using larger cookie cutters.   
For the icing mix one cup powered sugar and the juice of one lemon until it slightly runny   
When the scones are cooled drizzle the lemon icing over them. Perfect with a cup of tea!

post: Is that a look that you do not know what a mother is? And because of that, you are giving me the angry confused look? A mother is mold that grows on the surface of vinegar after a duration of time. You can take a piece of it, and add it to wine, to turn that as well into a quality vinegar, and grow/make another mother. It is faster to do if someone already has one, or you can buy it. But anyone can make one...you and Timow, really.

Question of scones - a great tip is when they come out of the oven, wrap them in a clean linen or muslin cloth.  This keeps them warm and quite moist, but a friend of mine who runs a coffee shop in Kent, always puts them in the microwave just for about 20 seconds to warm them through before serving. I am British (I bought your food processor from you last year) and we regularly have home-baked scones and they are always much nicer served warm! good luck

This is a place I frequent often. As it's a little hole in the wall, I normally get a takeaway. The daily special of a beef/lamb/chicken curry, veg curry, daal and rice for 10CHF. Very cheap and very good.   
I must stress though, although the place is called India Street Food, the food they serve is Sri Lankan, not Indian. You get all sorts of Sri Lankan curries, rice dishes (biryani) and pastries (samosas) as well as delicious kottu roti. The food might read as it's Indian, but it's Sri Lankan. The address is Langstrasse 213, 8005 Zurich. I will try the masala chai next time round.   
The other place I eat Sri Lankan food at is Friend's Corner, a short 5 minute walk from this place. They have a simple café with tables and chairs to dine in.    
Between the 2, I prefer the food at India Street Food.

There are some other makes of water filter, and I'm sure you can find them if you look, but your comment about making it "safe" is a little off the mark.   
These sorts of filters are intended to remove various minerals and trace amounts of heavy metals from the water. Tapwater is perfectly safe to begin with.    
Also worth noting that not all of them reduce water hardness, which for many people is the main reason to use them.

It's a small community; I think a small group of Chinese/Thai/Vietnamese own and/or run and/or work in most of the Asian supermarkets and restaruants in Basel.   
Once one decides it's not worth working on Sunday then their families all stop wanting to work and the other venues lose their staff.   Pretty quickly, you end up where we are now; with them all shut.  Luckily Saigon Moon is still open (most) Sundays.   
The Sri Lankan place behind Burger King near SBB (run by Sri Lankans or Indians, I'm not sure) is not affected by this so is still open

So I had some left over chickpeas & green lentils and wanted something different from curry or middle eastern food. Veggie burgers can be made very tasty if you add plenty of spice to the mix. Here's my recipe, feel free to add yours:   
For 5ish 120g burgers:    
- 100g dry green lentils 
- 200g of canned (wet) chickpeas or dried 
- 1-2 eggs 
- 1 onion medium size 
- 4 cloves of garlic 
- 3 dried large red chilies, to taste (I imagine any other chili works) 
- 2 tbsp madras curry powder 
- salt to taste 
- oil   
cook lentils & chickpeas together in a saucepan, the way you usually would, till tender. Pour away the liquid in sieve (reserve some liquid) and set aside.   
Chop the onion in half then widthwise so you get thin strands, chop up garlic and red chilies. Heat the oil in a frying pan, and when hot put in the onion and chili. Fry and stir every minute or so till the onion goes golden brown and add the garlic, fry for another minute then add the curry powder, mix for 30s and remove from heat.   
Next step can be done in batches if you want. Put the spice mix in the mixer, then add the lentils + chickpeas and the eggs. Add a little liquid then whizz till it becomes a fairly uniform paste. Next form the burgers with your hands, and put each one in clingfilm so they keep their shape, and refrigerate the lot for 1-2 hours. They keep for 2-3 days, and freeze very easily.   
To cook them, flour each side then fry at high heat till brown on one side, then flip. I don't recommend flipping them multiple times as they may fall apart. Serve with ketchup or anything that takes your fancy! Also, it's ideal hangover food if you need to go out drinking again soon afterwards.

post:
This is what a local SchreinerMeister (Master Cabinet Maker?) told me.  His lore is that wood work surfaces must be washed with lots of hot water and soap/disinfectant.  The water penetrates the wood, the wood swells, and destroys whatever is alien in it.   
Plastic has layers that harbor microbes, does not swell, and provides a good breeding ground for futher growth of unwanteds.   
The old fashioned way was to thoroughly scrub, with a scrubbing brush, lots of hot water and soap, all wooden work surfaces.   
I also still prefer natural wood to plastics.    
After using a board to cut anything meaty on -  board gets immersed in steaming water and Javel and then scrubbed with soap and left in sun to dry.

We purchased one of those super-automatic coffee machines for several well thought out reasons to replace our pod machine.  The machine was on super sale at inter-discount and had wondered why the discount.   
Flash ahead to now...the machine has malfunctioned in many ways: it will only grind coffee for 1 second despite what mode its on and something mechanical inside has broken ( a spring and some plastic bits ).  Despite the fact that the machine has a warranty...I can not find the original receipt.  I guess the machine must go to an independent repair facility.     
Has anyone used a machine repair shop?  Was it expensive?  On sale the machine was 299.00 (originally 899.00).  Its proven to be a failure within 6 months although it made consistent coffee.  If an non-warrantied repair is needed what are the chances that it would be more expensive than the machine was originally?

Tom - can you please tell me where you bought the salt?   
Coop salt has iodine or fluoride plus anticoagulants in it.    
Migros sea salt says 99.5% salt but doesn't say what the other 0.05% is but does say anticoagulants are included.    
My Landi didn't have salt at all.    
I ended up using 100% Himalayan salt and so far my brine is still clear, I don't think it will go cloudy. I made dill pickles last night - can't wait for 6 weeks to pass so I can open them up!!

post: Am i the only one who has a sudden desire to try to bounce mozzarella?

There are some excellent Swiss wines. It's dangerous to generalize, but I will.., Swiss wines are pretty old-world in style. They are usually best paired with food but some are enjoyable in their own depending on your own tastes and expectations. Reds are mostly Pinot noir and the other reds are also quite light in body relative to the same grapes in new world or further south. Zurich more a white wine territory but Switzerland is so small that there are no excuses for not visiting vineyards all over. Lots of less mainstream and/or local grapes being grown too.

Please do read the long threads that we have already on the forum about choosing gluten free foods....   
DB will insist (and I somewhat agree) that it's not hard to get gluten free food.    
We have a child who is gluten free and also diabetic, and on insulin injections, which means he has to eat to a food plan and eat a correctly measured amount of carbohydrate at the right time.   
Fruit and veg, no problem. Print of the words for 'gluten free' in French, Italian, German so you have them at restaurants. We get salads served with no sauce (no dressing), and same with meats. That's easier.   
In our experience it's actually unusual to have sauces, sausages, fries, thickened or dusted with wheat in Switzerland - it's more commonly maizena (maize flour) or potato flour used as the thickener. No problem finding potato crisps that contain only carb, oil and salt. Since you said gluten/corn/soy free, that pretty much leaves the common ones - potatoes and rice - as your staples I guess.    
We've had no problem with the 'paprika' flavoured crisps either. Unlike where we come from they don't add milk or gluten to the flavouring in the most common brand.   
I think perhaps powdered coconut or almond milk might be the way to go if you really need your milk substitute and need something very light and easy (powder sachets are easily obtained) - but the regular supermarkets will have coconut milk in UHT packaging for 'on the go', and possibly the corn flour. You can also get 'instant' mashed potato in sachets which, despite the packaging label, does not require boiling (we make it up using boiled water).    
You will find a good supply of fresh fruit and veg to keep you going, and certainly meat is not a problem (just ask for it cooked with salt and pepper and nothing else!) - and even the sausages and processed meat products are generally gluten-free. Fish will be a problem because it tends to be crumbed or fried...   
We have had absolutely no problem with potato chips (pommes frites) here - as they are normally just potato and oil, and no hidden flour or flavourings, just double check that the cook doesn't add any extra 'flavour' onto them, and you should be fine.
Baarcity is really good. Hope that terrasse will be also amazing.

I don't have the paperwork to hand, but I seem to remember that the duty-free allowance was much higher for people who were moving than for normal visitors.  We brought in over a hundred bottles of wine and ten bottles of spirits with no problem and no duty to pay.   
(Found it:  Up to 200 litres of alcohol below 25º can be imported duty and tax free and a maximum of 12 litres of alcohol over 25º.)    
We had to pack them all separately and inventory them individually, but the movers had all the appropriate forms.  Our movers insisted that we couldn't bring any bottles that had already been opened (due to the risk of spillage rather than any legal requirement) but otherwise we had no problems.

post:
I make my own flour mix. 
Chickpea flour (Kichererbsenmehl) can be found in Indian stores (cheaper than the Reformhaus), it has good "sticky" properties and helps to keep baked goods moist. 
Ground almonds or hazelnuts give a nice flavour to the mix and add protein.   
If you can tolerate rice flour it helps with making the baked goods fluffier. I usually mix in some potato starch or tapioca starch, arrow root flour, or whatever else I can find, because hubby can't tolerate rice.   
You really have to play around with it a bit, until you find the best mix for whatever you are trying to make. I have had good luck with soda breads and muffins.

post:
Forgive the braindump format of this....   
The Marmaris on Spalenring (tram stop Brausebad - 1/14 & 6) is a Turkish restaurant that also has a nice range of vegetarian options - and it is reasonably priced.    
Lily's on Claraplatz (trams 6, 8, 14, 15, 17)  is worth a look. Chateau Lapin / Hasenburg (Schneidergasse of Marktplatz) has a range of Swiss options which will please a vegetarian - e.g. some of the röstis plus a vegetarian crepe that they do. There is the Kelim (also Turkish) on the back of cinema street. Also I think Zum Isaak on Münsterplatz is worth a look.   
The Parterre restaurant at the Kaserne (Tram 8)has a fairly eclectic range of dishes and I think some vegetarian given the kind of clientele. If you want cheap daytime eats, the restaurant at the top Manor is alright. Also the Thai takeaway place on Claraplatz. Also the Kornhuus (near bus 34 stop Universität) and the Ono are worth a look - oh, and the Mandir that does Indian food - including an Ayurvedic menu is not far away.    
I have also heard good things about the vegetarian options at Jays.   
Cheers, 
Nick

post:
Swolman, I don't know where exactly you are writing from but you should find something distinctly unique to your town or area.   
Your Swiss hosts will appreciate something that is made locally in your region that has a story that you can relate to them.  For instance, if you are from New Jersey, bring Salt Water Taffy.  If you are from Wisconsin, bring some cheddar cheese.  If you are from the Pacific Northwest, bring some smoked salmon, etc.   
Find some distinctive liqueur or some local specialty and explain it to them and they will love it.  The more "local" the better.     
For example, my landlords, who are very, very Swiss but who are also very fun and open-minded LOVED the peppermint bark candy that I brought them one year for Christmas.  They had never heard of it before and they enjoyed handing it around to their other Swiss friends at one of their parties.  It became a cocktail/conversation item.

There's a couple of common failings (that I've made) to do with the yeast. Mostly in a bread machine, but the same applies to hand-mixed.   
1. If you're using dried yeast be warned about its lifespan. The danger is to think that as it's dried it will last forever, but in practice stuff that's a year or two old just doesn't work as well.  
2. Salt. Be careful that you don't put the yeast and salt in immediate proximity when you're adding the water. 
3. Use lukewarm water, not cold, to help get the yeast working. Conversely, very hot water will kill the yeast before it's started.   
Also be careful about the flour. I buy ours in France, so the naming conventions are different from the UK and CH, but most 'ordinary' flours are not strong enough (i.e. not a high enough gluten content). Look for flour specifically labelled for use in bread, and even then be sure that it's not referring to germanic bread, AKA brick.

post: Haha! Thanks. I will use parts of this for the feature.

Just a heads up, it is no longer necessary to cook pork to well done, which will almost always dry out a lean pork chop. The spirochetes that infected pork and caused Trichinosis has been eradicated from farmed pigs.   
When I fry them I always put them in foil for a few minutes afterwards, before serving. They continue to cook a very little bit, but the meat relaxes and gets more tender, and the juice gets redistributed through the whole peice of meat, also helping juiciness.   
Same principal as resting a roast for 10-20 minutes, but in smaller cuts the time is reduced.   
Also contrary to received wisdom, recent food science experiments have revealed it is best to turn frying or grilling meats a few times, the first time after they have lightly browned. Pressing gently on the meat with a spatula helps with even cooking and does not squeeze the juice out either, as once supposed. 'Sealing' doesn't seal juices in either, it's an old myth. But it does brown the surface nicely, which created new flavours, and leaves residues in the pan that will make a fabulous 'jus' or thin gravy when de-glazed with some water, stock, or wine. This is why roasts are often browned off slightly before being put in the oven.

Here is another recipe:   
4 Eggs 
75 g sugar 
55 g almond powder 
30 g flour 
100 g butter 
100 g dark chocolate   
Beat the eggs and sugar together till pale, then whisk in the almond powder and flour, melt butter and chocolate together and mix it in to the rest of the mixture, prepare your moulds, making sure they have been buttered and floured.   
And put into a pre heated oven at 200c and bake for 8-10 minutes

I just borrowed my Mother-in-Law's copy of the covent garden soup cookbook - plan to work my way through most of them!!   
Anyway here is their recipe: (I haven't tried it so can't review but I would think it would benefit from celery and stock instead of water)   
50g butter 
450g leeks, finely sliced 
225g potatoes, peeled and thinly sliced 
570ml water 
275ml milk 
75ml single cream 
salt and ground white pepper   
To Garnish:  150ml natural yogurt   
Method: 
melt the butter and cook the leeks and potatoes gently for 10 minutes in a covered saucepan, without colouring.  Add the water, cover, bring to the boil and simmer for about 20 minutes until the vegetables are tender.  Cool a little, then puree in a liquidiser.  Stir in the milk and cream and taste for seasoning.  Served garnished with a swirl of yogurt.

Comté is made in the Jura mountains in France, in Department 25 Franche-Comté, and Gruyères either in the Fribourg mountains, or the Jura mountains in Switzerland. The mountains and the grass on both sides of the border are just the same- when I walk around here in the meadows (I live right on the border) I can assure you you can't see the difference - I often have no idea which side of the border I am on.   
Yes, Comté and Gruyères are very similar, and yet quite different. And like Cheddar, range from the sublime artisan made trad matured cheese, and the ridiculous factory young tasteless cheese.

Hi   
I am British who moved to Switzerland last year; hopefully my opinion therefore warrants some credibility. I would be careful with this concept. As mentioned before, your potential customer base in the UK is limited, but quite simply what about the prices ? I look at English products in the English book store for example and you pay crazy prices for English "mint sauce" or English mustard or English biscuits. I adore some of those products and occasionally we treat ourselves, but seldom is it part of the regular "shop".   
Now reverse this and you have a larger issue. The strength of the Swiss Franc. Food prices in the UK by CH standards are exceptionally competitive. If I will not pay 5 CHF for a pack of English biscuits, I will certainly not pay 8 GBP for some Swiss biscuits?    
Finally, the Economist comes out. The Franc will increase in value against the British Pound. The Swiss Bank, will stop artificially controlling the Franc and furthermore the British Pound will continue to devalue for the next 24-36 months.    
Sorry, but I think the odds are stacked against you    
Rich

Since fish cooks quickly, there's no need to stir it. I'd simply  place the pieces of fish into the (already cooked) simmering curry sauce  and spoon it over the fish. Keep the pot on a low heat, cover the pot  to allow the fish to steam. Occasionally, jiggle the pot gently to keep the sauce  moving and spoon more sauce over the fish if needed. Simmer for 5 to 10  minutes and dish up carefully.   
You could also try leaving the skin on the pieces of fish.

I have asked Naturkraftwerke by email, their dried natto contains 210μg Vitamin K2 per 100g, which is quite low compared to fresh natto. Supplement capsules mostly contain 75μg (Mercola's 150μg). Other fermented products also contain K2, like sauerkraut and kefir, because it is the bacteria that make the K2. Concentration is less, but at least I like the taste. According to the descriptions, natto is quite pungent and an acquired taste, so I am not sure if I would like it! Organ meat is reported to be a good source too. I just found this article that gives a very detailed description of all forms of vitamin K and in which foods contain it, I can really recommend looking at this:

Thanks for the suggestion but this (or similar) is the recipe I found all over in the internet. I like them that way, too. (btw: I cook them 10min in the microwave before adding butter/sugar and putting them in the oven, it's faster that way!) 
But I think there are very few main dishes I want to serve them made so sweet tasting as a side. Maybe I'm just not used to combine dessert with salty stuff. Besides, it started to taste boring to me.   
Anyway. My favorite so far is the recipe MissChievous gave. I changed it a bit, though. I cut the top and bottom off, so the squash stands firmly on my working plate. Then I peel them by cutting off the green peel. Only after that I cut it in half and spoon out the seeds. That way it's a lot easier to peel them than I thought it would be. 
Next, I cut them in in bite size chunks, and mix the lot with some oil and what I would call "indian" spices: turmeric, cumin, mango powder, cinnamon, chili, salt and pepper. I guess, you could simply add curry powder if you want. Spread it on a baking tray and bake them in he oven for about... maybe half an hour or so? When they start looking crispy on the top they're usually done. The first batch got yumm-yummed away right from the tray before they even had a chance to spot the main course. 
What I like in this recipe: the variations are endless. Try other spices and every time they turn out a bit different than the ones before. Never boring.

Did it last night, the turkey was extremely moist.  2 hrs 15 mins from start to table.   
We have a Miele but any oven should have these settings.  Ours is larger than some (the water container is in the top) so our turkey fit in, after minor surgery.   
Our turkey was from Coop, 104chf, 7.5 kg (16+ lb)   
1. Put a full size non-perforated pan at the lowest setting in the oven.  Pour maybe 2 cups chicken broth in it.   
2. Cut the backbone out of the turkey so you can lay it flat.  The butcher can do it or you can use a heavy duty pair of kitchen scissors with the notch for cutting through bone.  I ended up taking the thigh/legs off too (to break the joint, crush it on the counter and bend it backwards).  I put the turkey and his parts in the full size perforated pan that came with the oven.  I put the meat thermometer in the breast, although the leg joint would have worked too.  I put some salt on the skin and tucked some thyme around him.   
3. Set your oven like this: 
400F (200C), 30% humidity, 25 mins 
350F (176C), 60% humidity, core temp 170F (77C) 
It takes about 1.5 hours to reach temp.   
4. The skin was browned nicely, but we decided to make it a little browner so I set the oven to conventional heat at @375F and roasted it for about 15 mins.  It pushed the temp up but was worth it for the skin lovers.  Next time I will set the core temp to be 160, to make up for the 15 mins of skin roasting.   
4. Take the turkey out, cover with foil, and let it rest for 30 mins, the temp will get to 180F (82C)   
5. I am a simple gravy maker. I poured the roasting liquid in a large fry pan and reduced it by @ 1/2 (@10 mins) whisked together some cold water and arrowroot flour in a bowl, and slowly whisked that into the gravy and let it cook for a few mins.  Some butter and salt and it was done.
