post:
I'm a huge fan of simple, easy but good recipes, here are two tried and true favorites of mine for rhubarb.   
Nancy's rhubarb and yoghurt fool.     
Serves 8:   
Refreshing, simple and yet, a glamorous dessert.   
500g prepared rhubarb   
30g butter   
120g castor sugar (normal sugar is fine)   
1 carton (200g) of plain yoghurt   
         -o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o   
300ml cream  
30g castor sugar   
dark chocolate flakes or crystallised ginger to garnish   
Cut the rhubarb into small pieces. Put into an oven proof dish, cover and cook at 150°C for 45 minutes.  Stir in the butter and 120g castor sugar. Purèe in a blender or put through a fine sieve.   
Beat the yoghurt and cream with 30g of castor sugar until slightly thicker than the rhubarb purèe. Mix all together gently.  Pour into dessert glasses (if you have them) and chill. Decorate with grated chocolate or finely-chopped crystallised (candied) ginger.       
Got this recipe many many moons ago from my Aussie buddy Suzanne (cheers Suz).   
Rhubarb Champagne   
1 kilo rhubarb - roughly chopped   
3 lemons - sliced   
3 cups sugar   
4 1/2 litres water (mustn't be hot but helps to dissolve the sugar to mix)   
1 Tblsp white vinegar (cider vinegar is ideal)   
Mix together and let stand somewhere out of the way, (not in the fridge) for 2 days, I always like to cover it with a muslin cloth, in case of those creatures...   
Strain, bottle and seal. Plastic mineral bottles are perfect for this.   
Ready in two weeks.....   
This is not a syrup, but a wonderfully refreshing bubbly drink (non-alcoholic), lovely chilled, in summer.   
Ros   
P.S. It also freezes perfectly when cut up into the desired piece size, put in a bag (suck out all the air if you don't have a vacuum packer) and pop it into the freezer till you want it. It's often advocated to add 1 part sugar to 4-5 parts   rhubarb, but I've found packing without equally successful.   
P.P.S Look after your rhubarb plant, pulling the stalks away from the crown at ground level as opposed to   the stalks off (can lead to rotting of the crown) will mean you can have many years of delight from this great plant.

Old school Switzerland. 
When my grandfather passed away (early 80s) he had 50 kilos of sugar tucked away PLUS, canned goods, a freezer *full* of meat, and, and... 
My dad and uncles filled 2 station wagons of stuff - they gave it to an old age home.   
And "back then" they could actually fine you if you didn't have your "extra" supplies in order, according to my father. Not a problem when we lived in Italy... our next-door neighbor was a peasant who had is small plot of land and was growing food for half the village, LOL!

Just to let all whisky fans out there know that if you can't wait until December for your annual single malt whisky ship splurge, there is one being organised by the shop at Neumarkt 27 (the Gottfried Keller Haus).        
This is filling up (14 from 40 places gone as of yesterday, and it's not yet been advertised) so sign up quick if you want to go. CHF80 for I think 6 good size samples. (I am in no way affiliated with this shop besides a desire to keep it in forever in business.)    
I've just created a post rather than putting this in the calendar, as I'm not organising it, I'm unlikely to go (busy busy busy) and by the time anyone sees the entry the places will all be gone.   
Also, the shop is a great place to go if you want to try several excellent whiskies before buying.   
Cheers, Ali

Thanks everyone for your suggestions.  In case anyone else is looking for whisky glasses in the future, here's what I found out.   
Riedel was the only place I found which has the proper heavy good looking crystal  glasses - quite pricey though.  They had some other whisky tumblers which are okay, not quite so pretty and not quite so pricey. 
If you're ever thinking of going there, go well in advance of the date you need them for - they had only one each of my first two choices in the shop and it takes 4 weeks to order more.   
The Meister on Augustinerstrasse has whisky tumblers too, but none that are that great, except some VERY expensive ones.   
Jelmoli no longer sell any glasses/crockery at all, shame as that box set looks like just what I was after.   
Globus and Manor have a very limited selection and nothing you would call a good whisky tumbler.   
Villeroy and Boch (thank you Treverus) have some simple but pretty ones.   
I couldn't work out which was the whisky shop located somewhere between Fraumünster and the Rudolf Brun Brücke, but I did spend a very pleasant 45 minutes getting my own private whisky tasting at the shop at Neumarkt 27 (the Gottfried Keller Haus).  They have about 20 open bottles that you can taste and the very nice lady let me try quite a few of them including an excellent bottle which is now sitting on my shelf.  If you are interested, there is a whisky tasting on 4 Nov which is filling up (14 from 40 places gone as of yesterday, and it's not yet been advertised) so sign up quick if you want to go.  CHF80 for I think 6 good size samples.  (I am in no way affiliated with this shop besides a desire to keep it forever in business.)  They don't sell whisky tumblers though.         
Other important findings are that the Barokoko on Pelikanstrasse has some delightful antique beer/schnaps/etc (but not whisky) glasses that are not toooo pricey, was rather taken by some lovely beer mugs from a pub in Nidwalden from around 1900.  The Echo artdeco shop on Talacker has some old glasses too, unfortunately did not have time to see them all as they're kept in another building.   
And finally, I discovered that proper whisky buffs do not do tumblers.  They do nosing glasses of some description, a la les whisky-ships.  You live and learn.     
Cheers everyone, and happy drinking.    
Hic.

Spaghetti squash is very easy to find in Swiss romande if you know your way around the farm markets, etc.    
In this area of la cote, these places have them:   
Farm in Eysins, woman is from Canada (Quebec) and has the most variety of pumpkins I have ever found in Switzerland--spaghetti, butternut, acorn, jack-o-lanterns, and some other varieties that I didn't even know existed as well.   
Farm market in Nyon on Saturday, there are a number of stands that have it.   
The Signy Centre Coop has it from time to time.   
Some other local farms with farm stands I have also seen it.   
And there is something called 'Fete de la Courge', or something similar, ie. Pumpkin Festival, just outside of St. Prex in autumn, and it is pumpkin heaven. Every pumpkin you want, you will find. You can also make contact with the farmers and growers directly, to ensure your supply for the season.   
Edited to add--I also assume someone must sell it at the Sunday Divonne market, just over the border in France, as they have everything there, although I have not personally purchased it there.

Tom;   
You are quite correct, technically. My sincere apologies.   
FRATELLI LONGOBARDI, location Scafati, Italia, technically uses sucrose as an acidity prevention or balance additive in all Pomodoro Pulpa (Diced) and Pelati (Peeled) products.    
This is a sweetener, if you will, and not actually sugar. My wife and I learned this in a cooking class in Lago Di Como, Lombardia. Think about it: The canned tomato product would become very acid ( as experienced in some very unspeakable American restaurants ) if they did not add sucrose, as does Lombardi, and Barrilla.   
Ergo the sweetness.

Hi every one! 
If you are still looking for yuzu trees, please have a look at the following websites: 
-  
-  
-  
-    
I have ordered from them and already planted a small yuzu in my garden at the lake side near Geneva this spring! 
At Baches, the citrus are grafted on poncirus trifoliata which enhance further the hardiness and allows to get fruits earlier (from seeds, you can wait until 15 years for the 1st fruit...). Citrusbali has grafted my second yuzu tree on fyling dragon, which shall keep the tree smaller 
There are many other frost hardy citrus that can be eaten; I have also in the ground the Ichang Lemon, soon the Segentrange hybrid US 119 (sweet like a mediterranean orange), Satsuma Owari (Japanese mandarin seedless) and Changsha Mandarin (old Chinese cultivar), that's a fiew of them and hope to have fruits next year! All those citrus are said to be frost hardy until -10C. Would love to compare my experiences with other frost hardy citrus grower in Switzerland! 
Greeting from Geneva 
Gerd

The vegetable you are referring to is called  , which is closely related to the cauliflower (Broccoli and Cauliflower are members of the same cabbage family).  It is best during the colder months of the year (October-April), although it does begin showing up at the market in September.  This year is a bit unusual in that everything is coming about one month early, so I am not surprised that Romanesco is already at the market.  It can be boiled or steamed just like broccoli or cauliflower...you can cook the entire head in boiling, well-salted water for about 15 minutes, let it cool, then detach the little florets, and sauté them in some butter... Migros and Coop will carry this vegetable (probably a bit later in the year), but they are better when purchased fresh at the market...   
Jack

Get some good over the counter chorizo and paprika, rip up the chorizo in to the pan, (big paella pan, or wok like thing) plenty of GOOD olive oil on a medium to low heat, (you don't want to fry it). Spanish onion diced as finely as possible, in it goes, garlic, pressed then diced, in it goes, Thyme, plenty of it and also some paprika, and mix it all up.     Boil water with chicken stock, (not to much remember this will make it really salty if you put too much stock in) The 'marigold' veg or chicken stock is the best. About a litre of water+ stock add it to the wok then pour in your paella rice, (the Spanish do it in the shape of a cross). Add plenty of paprika now, to get that red colour.     Now I usually put chicken and king prawns in mine, prepare the chicken at the same time as the above method, breast meat is easier to dice and chuck in but I have found chicken thighs with bones chucked in can give the richer flavour. Leave the addition of the prawns till later, you don't want tough overly cooked meat. You can (and probably should) add muscles (they must be prepared carefully and added close to the end of cooking.)     Peas can be added and I think it is nice to serve with crusty bread and a sliced Spanish orange.

Oranges can be from most of the countries around the Med, like Morocco, Israel, Italy and Spain   
Melons tend to be from Ghana or Egypt   
Figues from Turkey and Lebanon   
Dates from Tunisia and Iran, and yes Israel   
Beans either from local suppliers or from Egypt   
Asparagus from local suppliers or from France or China   
Flowers from local suppliers or from the Netherlands or from Chile   
Green salads from local suppliers   
Cheese from local suppliers , but also from France, Italy, Greece, Egypt, GreatBritain, Netherlands and others   
Berries of all kinds from local suppliers, but also from California

Jack's recipe is pretty much the same as the one I use & I get consistantly excellent results too.   
For 1 large loaf: 
500g of weissmehl. 
60g butter. 
325 ml Milk. 
30g fresh yeast liquified with a good teaspoon of sugar & added to the milk. 
1 good teaspoon of sea salt. 
yolk of an egg with a splash of milk brushed over the loaf just before you pop it in the oven.

Agree - I hate doing exercise for the sake of exercise. I would rather do a sport where you also have support from team members. It doesn't have to be at an elite level.       I would add that you should try to eat soon after exercise.    
In the example of blood sugar regulation Economisto mentions, exercise really increases your insulin sensitivity. So if you are going to eat carbs, do it then as you'll get more sugar being stored as glycogen (quick release energy). This has two immediate benefits: 1) less excess carb being transfered to fat; and, 2) you'll feel more energetic as a result (remember that old saying that doing exercise gives you energy?).   
This meal needs to be within 15-60 minutes post exercise (ideally within 45 minutes), so you should have it ready in advance.    
However, don't overburden your meal with carbs, you should include a good load of protein to help build/repair muscle.

You get Black Pasta; so why not rice?     Black Pasta  Add to the  , besides normal ingredients, one cuttlefish' ink for each 3 oz. of flour and some water. 
Ink, commonly called sepia, is taken from little bladders that are in mollusk internal sacs. 
We'll obtain a grayish pasta and not a very black one, because eggs weaken much the sepia coloring power. 
Black pasta is mainly used to prepare fettuccine or pappardelle to be served with sea sauces (cuttlefish, squids, calamaries and mollusks)

post:
That is the big difference between US and European law. Here we accept accidents can and do, happen, we also take a sense of responsibility. Providing the accident was not due to blatent negligence, it's treated as an accident and compèensation is limited to a reasonable amount. By getting a minor burn from hot coffee, doesn't give you an automatic right to sip pina coladas for the rest of your life doing nothing. As for "physcological damage", this is pure fantasy, but difficult to prove otherwise.   
To take the well known example, we can all sue MacDonnalds as we're too stupid to work out that the coffee maybe hot. It's the consumer who keeps MacDonnalds in business and it's MacDonnalds who pays out to individuals, so each article purchased from Macdonnalds, a certain percentage goes to paying out spurrious law suits.    
Bottom line is, your hamburger costs more than it should as some idiot judge rules in favour of a claimant who so say, is too stupid to realise coffee maybe hot but not stupid enough to find an lawyer and sue !

Ok this is what I found and is the recipe for a basic (vanilla) muffin 
It makes 10-11 standard size muffins:     Ingredients:   10 oz (280 gr) plain flour *   2 teaspoons (10 ml) baking powder   ½ teaspoon (2.5 ml) bicarbonate of soda   ¼ teaspoon (1.2 ml) salt   1 egg   3-5 oz (85-140 g) fine white granulated sugar or light brown soft sugar   4 fl oz (120 ml) plain yogurt   5 fl oz (150 ml) milk (adjust if necessary to give a good dropping consistency-not too thick, not too thin)   3 fl oz (90 ml) vegetable oil   1 teaspoon (5 ml) vanilla essence   Methods:   1 Prepare muffin tins with liners or grease. Preheat oven to 375-400 F (190-200 C) for a conventional oven, Gas Mark 5-6   2 In a large bowl sift together flour, baking powder, bicarbonate of soda and salt   3 In a separate bowl, beat egg with fork. Stir in sugar, yogurt, milk, oil and vanilla   4 Scrape all liquid mixture into dry. Using a metal spoon, stir lightly until evenly combined, scraping the sides and bottom of the bowl as you stir. This mixture should take only about 30 seconds. Batter should have good dropping consistency. (do not mind lumps)   5 Fill muffin cups three quarters full and bake for about 20 minutes     (Taken out of Muffins by Susan Reimer)

post:
Mostly dumb luck, I think, a lot of sun and some nicely drained pots. I had some seeds - some were black forest variety, others were a mini type from the coop, I think. I started a few of them in a small pot with basic soil from the Landi. When they got to be about 4" tall, I put them all into a 50 cm wide pot - I had about 8 plants. They were in a very sunny location. I think 4 -6 survived, and I have these massive plants with big leaves and flowers. I have both male and female flowers. The male flowers grow on the vine, the female ones  have a little zucchini attached. We're not letting them grow to be full zucchini since we only want the flowers. Last week, because there was a lot of crowding, I cut back some of the plants, and I still have a bunch of flowers popping up.    
The flowers are beautiful, very delicate. My absolute favorite way to make them is to saute them in a little butter, add a beaten egg, and maybe some ham or mild cheese. My husband was getting tired of the egg thing, however, hence my need for new recipes.

post:
Very easy: Döner Kebab! I know there is a shop at pretty much any corner of Zurich pretending to sell it... but I have seen a funny program on the German TV lately: The control of the "Ordnungsamt" was checking restaurants in Berlin for cleanliness, alcohol licenses and other rules and there I learned: the **** they serve here would be illegal in Germany!  
In order to call it Döner Kebab in my home, it has to be meat, stacked in layers on a grill. Minced meat is only acceptable if it is a minor ingredient, less than 20%. Here it is 100% and comes usually not directly from the grill, but some box where the cut minced meat is kept luke-warm. This does not only taste ******, it must be the best breeding ground for bacteria ever invented... and do not get me started that they want 10 CHFs for that.   
So: A Kebab made out of proper meat which is grilled on a flaming gas grill and comes directly from the stick... with fresh salad, onions and spices topped with a good yogurt sauce.   
P.S: If you really believe you have found that place in ZH, please share!

I've never seen Zweifel products in the US (or actually, outside of CH/DE). 
Same goes for Movenpick and Orelmann's.   
Lindt DOES have stores in the US, but of varying stocks.  The one in Chicago is pretty good, but that's a trip from Arizona.   
My sister was excited to see Emmi products at her local supermarket.  She hasn't been to visit yet, but thinks Bircher Muesli is the best thing since sliced bread.  You might be able to get it around you - I'm pretty sure Safeway has some sort of local branch in Arizona (in Chicago it's Dominick's.).   
For substitution, I'd try Pringles in place of Zweifel.  There are a few other 'potato powder' pressed chips out there, Pringles just being the most prevalent.  They're not as good, but could do in a pinch.   
I'd also hit up your local dairy or ice cream shop - not something like Coldstone, but a local, homemade ice cream.  In Chicago, we have Oberweiss and a few others - and I think they're right on par with Movenpick.   
Good luck!

post:
We bumped into the Gaucho event occuring at Kaufleuten last night.   
For CHF 75 you get an apero (nice gingery thing), a salad, all you can eat main and then a dessert and digestif.   
The main deal here is the meat, in particular the excellent Argentinian beef.  I enjoyed a sausage and some well done ribs (full of flavour, falling off the bone), but enjoyed the rare sirloin most.  This is the first time I've had properly rare beef in Zürich.  The only slight niggle was that they ran out of chimichurri and we had to concoct our own hot sauce using tabasco and the innocuous red paste on the table.  The digestif involved Fernet Branca, which I understand cures all.   
It's a moveable feast, which roams the pampas of Switzerland:

Starter = Capuns ( ) from Graubünden   
Mains = the Zurich Geschnetzeltes with loads of cream and white wine and mushrooms and crispy Rösti   
Dessert = Panna cotta ( ) with homemade tuiles   
Cheese = nice selection of artisan cheeses from Valais and Graubünden   
All washed down with a nice selection of wines   and finished off with a good Grappa

Nicky takes her responsibilites very seriously. She knows we cannot afford to lose good Mods  - even temporarily. No food risks to be taken.

I second the use of metal bottles, I wouldn't use extra acidic drinks in them if they are aluminum, though. SIGG was not ahead of the game at all, the bottles were great, trendy and all, but as said, did contain  lining inside. It was the Canadian gov that banned import and sale of these bottles first, that made SIGG rid of the lining, and only a year or so ago, which was quite late. Other govs put pressure later on, too.    
The plastic bottles leak, especially if washed or "sterilized" as somebody put it by hot water. Same goes for plastic BPA baby bottles, they are especially dangerous if the milk in it is hot or people wash them in the dishwasher on hot cycle. The hard plastic sport blueish bottles, that are meant for re-using, unless they clearly say they are BPA free, always contain plastic softener agents. Same goes for unsafe plastic containers that get shoved in microwave ovens.    
We replaced all our tupper wear and plastic tubs and kid plastic things with BPA free stuff, glass or metals. It only makes sense, it is cheaper, too. I grew up mostly without disposable crap, cotton, linen, glass and metal, so it is nice to somewhat go back in time, plus it's more esthetic. Plastic is cheap and ugly.
Irony, I think I'd call it.  Ready meals (once called TV Dinners) are not as popular in Italian culture as they might well be in that of Anglophobes

I moved to Switzerland  , and am now studying German at level A1. I hope to be able to work full time next year if I have some reasonable level of fluency.   
During the times I'm not studying, I'm mostly cycling or running as well as being the   as my wife is working full time. Cooking has never been a strong point of mine, mainly due to laziness: I could rarely be arsed to cook just for myself, so I ate lots of (mostly healthy) takeaway or prepared foods (bottled M&S pasta sauces with pasta).   
Anyway, things have changed now, so I'm trying to build a collection of recipes, most of them simple. I thought it would be a good exercise for me to translate recipes from German to English, and whilst I'm at it, post any good ones here. Maybe others will also enjoy them.   
So here's one I cooked tonight, a great Spring dish with asparagus being in season right now.     
Für 4 Personen 
Zubereitung: ca. 35 Minuten   
300-400g  Rigatoni 
500g grüne Spargeln, gerüstet, schräg in 3-4cm  lange Stücke geschitten 
250g Cherrytomaten 
1 EL gehackter Oregano 
2 EL Butter 
1 Handvoll Rucola 
2 Kugeln Mozzarella, von  Hand halbiert 
schwarzer Pfeffer aus der Mühle 
Sbrinz AOC (or Parmesan),  gerieben, nach Belieben   
1) Rigatoni in  siedendem Salzwasser al dente kochen. Spargeln in den letzten 4-5  Minuten mitgaren. Alles sorgfältig abgiessen, abtropfen lassen. 
2) Tomaten, Oregano und Butter erhitzen, mit dem Rucola zu  den Rigatoni mischen. 
3) Rigatoni in einer vorgewärmten  Schlüssel oder vorgewärmten tiefen Tellern anrichten. Pro Person 1  Mozzarella-Hälfte drauflegen, grosszügig mit Pfeffer würzen. Nach  Belieben mit Sbrinz bestreuen.     Serves 4 
Cooking time: approximately 35 minutes   
300-400g rigatoni 
 500g green asparagus, prepared (spears removed), cut diagonally into  3-4cm pieces 
250g cherry tomatoes 
1 TBSP  chopped oregano 
 2 TBSP butter 
 1 handfull of rocket 
2 balls of mozzarella, halved by  hand 
freshly ground black pepper 
grated  Sbrinz (or parmesan) to your taste   
1)  Cook rigatoni in salted boiling water. Add the asparagus in the last 4-5  minutes. Carefully drain. 
 2) Heat up the tomato, oregano and butter. Mix with the rocket and then  the rigatoni. 
3) Serve the rigatoni in a warm bowl or  warm deep plate. For each person lay out half a ball of mozzarela,  generously seasoned with pepper. Sprinkle with parmesan cheese to your  taste.   
Bon app!

Hello sunflower76, 
Like your husband, I am also a fan of white chocolate and have lots of recipes. If you go on to bbc.co.uk/goodfood, you will have access to thousands of fantastic recipes, just put into the search the recipe you would like to find. I also use google, once again put in the recipe you want to find and it will be there. 
 My family like 'white chocolate creme brulee', white chocolate cheesecake and if you want a quick fix that is a bit healthier, put some double cream into a pan, heat it up gently ( don't let it boil) when it's hot remove it from the heat, drop in some white chocolate and stir until it melts and then pour it over some summer fruits. You can make it a bit more of a dessert by crumbling some shortbread bicuits over it.

Where I come from 'burek' is made with meat only, if it is filled with cheese (closest you can find here is cottage cheese) or vegetables (diced potatoes, courgettes or spinach) then it is not burek. But that is a moot point. I do not know of any place in Geneva that makes this kind of pastry and Turkish restaurants have something with a similar name that is not at all the same thing.    
What you can do is make it at home, larger Coops now stock the pastry made by Klas in their Balkan section. What I find more difficult is meat -- somehow the beef mince you can get here does not produce the desired effect. I think it is too lean.

The thread about the Master Chef series triggered a curiosity...    
For the "foodies" among us, was there a particular trigger that inspired a marked interest in food for you beyond simple consumption of fuel?     
When I was growing up, my sis was the one who helped mom in the kitchen the most often. My kitchen activities were almost exclusively devoted to the avoidance of doing dishes   and baking for special occasions.    
Meanwhile, once I began cooking for myself, I noticed that cooking things a certain way or substituting one ingredient for another tended to change how I felt after eating. The main one for me was that my mother always used red kidney beans for her chili and for some reason, I always had an intense pressure in my chest after eating Mom's chili. I remember crying to her about how I felt and her not believing me.   I use pinto beans for my chili and never have a problem. I wonder what the difference is?     
The other trigger for me was based actually on selfishness combined with a desire to eat "healthier"... My friend and roommate allowed the younger sister of another friend to come stay with us when she was having some hard times. Neither the friend nor the sister could be bothered to buy anything but the most generic of groceries BUT always happily made use of the more expensive things I would buy.   
So, as I was already overweight anyhow, I decided it was a good time to go on a diet.   I started buying "fat free" items including organic cookies using carob instead of chocolate chips, skim milk, skinless chicken, rice instead of pasta, etc etc. I started cooking with the intent of having as little fat as possible... miraculously, people stopped eating my food.    
That time spent though, trying to find recipes that tasted good AND had low fat content was what inspired my curiosity for cooking. Of course now my food goes both ways... some (relatively) healthy food for daily cooking but some very rich dishes and desserts for special occasions.

I picked up ingredients to make the brownies again while shopping with  m-i-l yesterday and was pointed to a different chocolate bar for baking.  I'll see how it goes. I'd say from the ingredient list, it sounds like a low-cholesterol cheesecake?

Just want to put a good word in for a cook book that has come out:     
It's in German - so if you're not interested in a book in this language, read no further ....    
It's a fabulous, independent book from the "makers" of   - a German language food blog - and includes "authentic" recipes from all over Switzerland. "Authentic" meaning, what one actually eats today in these areas. An example from Basle is, for instance, is from the St. Johann neighbourhood and is a receipe involving tabbouleh, hummus and malawah.    
There are recipes for Korean aubergine salad, lemon risotto, lamb with chestnut and fig sauce, trout with radish sauce, lentil salad with avacado and rucola - in short, very creative dishes and desserts.   
The book also includes portraits of the users who submitted the recipes, so you'll get a glimpse of real people living in Switzerland today.   
Cosmopolitan, international and very refreshing - and no, I'm not affiliated, just an avid cookbook collector

post:
Hi all,   
It's nice to see such enthusiasm on the wine bore thread. Before moving to Switzerland I'd been working at the Experimental Winery and regularly assisting with an 'Introduction to Wine' course at Purdue University. If there's any interest I could collect some of my presentation materials from the course and we could meet weekly to have a course and tastings and the end of each presentation.   
There's been a lot of information from Planthead on what basic characteristics to expect from wine varietals, and while I think that's a great crib note for wine shopping there's so much more to the subtle aromas and characteristics of wine dependent on the 'terroir', production method, etc...   
I'd just like to drop a quick note, for complete wine nouveaus on the classification systems used for European wines, which might make a handy list when you go shopping for a gift, or even for an ejoyable evening at home. So here goes:   
Basically the tiered quality ranking system runs along the lines of: 
Table Wine 
Regional Wine 
Quality Tested Wines 
Highest Quality Tested, Compliance Guaranteed Wines   
Across the EU most nations conform to this tiered format with their own naming systems, here they are:    -- Wines designated AOC are of the highest  quality and have passed the tight regulations on grape growing and  controlling the alcohol content.  -- These are regulated in the same  way as the AOC wines, considered less quality and are beginning to be phased out of  the classification system.  -- These wines have 100% of  one type of grape grown from a specific region only and are strictly  regulated.  -- This "table wine" varies  in alcohol content and is of the lowest quality usually, for everyday  occasions.      -- Denotes the  highest quality Italian wines. DOCG measures insure that each bottle is  counted, providing an exact measure of production, and contains a  government seal that is applied by hand. It is a costly procedure,  usually reserved for expensive wines.   -- Wines that fall under the DOC category must be made in specified,  government defined zones, in accordance to particular regulations that  are intended to preserve the wine's character that is uniquely derived  from the country's individual regions.   -- Generally denotes ubiquitous tables wines grown in specific regions  throughout Italy.  --  Mainly comprised of Italian table wines, whose  criteria is only that they be made from grapes grown in Italy. These are  often made by blended grapes from separate regions.  --This status guarantees that  wines from an area have consistently performed at the highest quality  level for a number of years.  -- Wines  carrying the DO label must meet the approved government standards. It is this regulation which in part ensures the wines from each of  the regions within Spain maintain their unique local characteristics.  -- A  notch lower, but these wines must, in the same way as DO approved wines,  carry a vintage date and regional identification.  -- These wines  fall outside the DO system. They are  table wines that do not carry  vintage dates or regional identification. More often than not, they are a  blend of wines from many regions and vintages.  -- These wines   may carry a vintage date and the name of the area from which they  originate. These wines are typically made from grapes or blends of  grapes not approved by the local Consejo Regulador.  -- The  regulations are as QbA with the additions that the grapes have to be  solely from the district stated and no alcohol enrichments or  chaptalization have taken place.   -- These wines have to obey the regional appellation laws. These laws  ensure that the wine is from one  specific wine-growing region, is made of approved grape varieties and  reached sufficient ripeness for a quality wine.  -- Enhanced Tafelwein, which  has to be made with grapes from one of the 19 specific districts, which  is specified on the label. The wine has to be marked as "Trocken" (dry)  or "Halbtrocken" (medium-dry).  -- Denotes the lowest quality German wines, not many  are exported.   -- The wines must conform to the legal definition of  “Qualitätswein” (quality wine) and are selected by a process of rigorous  blind tasting to ensure a high wine quality.  -- “Certified” wine.  Prädikatswein wines are the highest quality Austrian wines and are  produced from specific grapes grown in a selected region.  -- Wine of quality.  These wines are light and simple, derived from less-ripened grapes grown  in a specific wine region.  -- Table wine. There are  two types of tafelwein wines: landwein and tafelwein.  wines are table wines that  are made from officially designated grape varieties.  wines are simply table wines.      --   The only classification of Portuguese wines. Each of the 39 DO wine  denominations require thorough testing and are given a certified test  number, which must be displayed on the bottle. DO Porto and Madeira each  have separate governing bodies and regulations.   
It's plenty of info I know, but I often tell people who have no knowledge of wines to start off by determining what taste/smell characteristics they like from their wines and then buy according to this ranking. Keep in mind that there are many poorer wine producers (esp. across Europe) who can't afford to get certified, but produce amazing wines themselves. This is just a starting point for the layman at the wine store. This is a little background on old world wines (French wines have their own Bible sized booklet), which are a good place  to start tasting. Many newcomers & prissy connosieurs find it  difficult/refuse to palate the New World wines with their bold earthy  tones (see, Malbec, Pinotage, etc...).   
As my boss always said (and he's dined with Kind Carlos & Jacques Chirac), he'd almost never spend more than $20 or 30€ on a bottle of wine. I've had a glass on Romanee Conti Premier Cru which was valued at about $1300 a bottle, I can tell you that the taste of the wine does not necessarily improve linearly (or exponentially as wine merchants would have you believe) with the price. Leave the winos to blow their own money, and be smart with yours.   
If you have any questions about wine I'd love to help, just feel free to ask here or shoot me a message. Please remember I've not worked long in the industry, so while I know how to make different wines, and how they are produced, I'm nowhere close to being even an amateur (au contraire, my wines often tasted like jet fuel/moonshine).   
P.S. Mods can feel free to combine this with the original thread, I just thought I'd put out an offer for a course, and that this was too long a post.

I noticed one thing here though - the people who tend the seafood counters at Migros/Coop know very little about what fresh seafood looks like - maybe they assume that since it's thawed out, it wouldn't matter but really it does. If the fish was already stale when they froze it, it would be the same once it's thawed...or maybe even worse. =.=

Well, after going to a new Italian restaurant last night that opened just a stones throw away from me I felt compelled to give it a big shoutout. THe restaurant is:             
The place opened around a month or two ago but I never got around to going, as Mezzo is basically at the end of my road and my friend always goes there out of habit. Anyway, a colleague was buying dinner and liked Italian, so I remembered the new place and thought i'd give it a try.   
The layout is not the usual restaurant layout... it's essentially a thin strip of tables running parallel to a loooong bar, but is nicely decked out and tastefully modern. I think there's also a back-room eating area, but didn't really have a nose around.   
Anyway decor schmecor, onto the food. I opened the menu and immediately thought "prices look decent". 17-20 CHF for a "regular" topped pizza, ranging to a maximum of 26CHF for the "fancy" topped pizzas. I settled on a Calzone, while my friend settled on a Thonno.   
The Calzone arrived and I almost called the police, momentarily thinking it was the corpse of a small child, such was the size of the beast (it literally almost hung off the plate), drizzled in tomato sauce. Anyway to cut a short story shorter, the Calzone was possibly the best I have ever had... and certainly better than any pizza i've had in Mezzo. It was packed full of delicious topping (inning?), and the taste was simply sublime. I actually finished the beast, despite it being half my bodyweight.   
 My colleagues Thonno was also of a good size, and looked perfectly cooked. He also said it tasted amazing.   
In short, two amazing pizzas and two large cokes for 49 CHF. Awesome value for money in my opinion given the size and quality of the food we had.   
Five stars, highly reccommended.

The first thing to remember is the things that are inexpensive in your home country won't necessarily be cheap here.  This sounds obvious, but I've met quite a few people who are surprised when, e.g., their budget Mexican dish turns out to be expensive and difficult to source here.   
The second thing is to look for seasonal produce.  Both markets and supermarkets may have a glut and lower prices.   
Cut down on meat here, as it's very expensive compared to veg.

I actually prefer a high quality Ripasso to a low quality Amarone.  Life is too short for bad wine.   
Ripasso - A brilliant concept for increasing the amount of flavor and interest in basic Valpolicella. The Valpolicella wine is passed over unpressed but drained must of an Amarone. The bittersweet intensity of the Amarone is imparted, in a small way, to the basic Valpolicella, possibly with the help of a minor secondary refermentation

post:
This has been discussed before on EF, but I'm curious -- what concern about fluoridation can you understand?  ? The insidious plot to impose a communist regime (up there with those other evils, childhood immunisation and mental health programs)? Ku Klux Klan loony  's assertion that fluoridation is a Jewish plot to weaken the white race?   
The main objection to fluoride is that fluorine is a poisonous gas. Indeed. And so is chlorine; it killed well over 1,000 soldiers in WWI when deployed by German (and Allied) forces. Salts of fluorine and chlorine present no such worries, though. Is anyone concerned about sodium chloride -- apart from the fear of hypertension? Why this concern over minute concentrations of fluorosilicilic acid in drinking water?   
The OP mentions that larger amounts of ground water than usual are currently present in Zurich's tap water. Some ground water in mountainous areas naturally contains fluoride ion concentrations of up to 50 mg/L ( ); the recommended rate of fluoridation of municipal drinking water is around 1 mg/L. Better stop drinking Zuri water, then, and turn to the bottle ... of expensive mineral water, that is. Oh ... except that bottled mineral water can contain naturally-occurring levels of fluoride well in excess of 1 mg/L.   
Apparently people in Switzerland eschew fluoridated water for the "preferred" solution of adding fluoride to their chloride intake -- via common table salt. Stronger teeth in exchange for increased rate of cerebral stroke and cardiovascular problems.

Olive Oil Source: Cooking with Olive Oil     
"Trans Fatty acids: Olive oil has no trans fatty acids.  When an oil 
is partially hydrogenated it can be in the cis or trans conformation 
which refers to which side of the fatty acid double bond the hydrogen 
is on. Olive oil is not a trans fatty acid because it has not been 
partially hydrogenated in a factory to make it solid at room 
temperature like margarine has.  Trans fat is created by bubbling 
hydrogen through 250 to 400 degree hot vegetable oil in the presence 
of a metal catalyst, usually nickel or platinum. The process can take 
several hours. You cannot accidentally make trans or saturated fatty 
acids at home on your range when heating olive oil or other oils."

Meat is far different from poultry or fish when it comes to holding it. Most beef in the states, except in supermarkets with Fresh being in thier mottoe such as Meijers in Michigan, is aged atleast 16 days, and Chop Houses in Chicago and Montreal will age the beef for as long as 64 days. Coloration in beef is only a sign of the aging, well, of course it it looks like an oil spill on the highway this is something different. True, expensive quality cuts of beef are aged, and will have green coloration in them. Dark coloration is a sign of freshly cut meat coming in contact with oxygen, which is perfectly normal. Look at any beef jerky or the like, they are all dark in coloration. Smell unless held outside the danger zone, comes with age or oxygen contact. When you buy at the butcher, you should always inspect the product before you buy it. It won't ever magically turn on you from 1 hour to the next with out outside intervention; you perhaps. However, the way you described your transport, this shouldn't be causing it.  
Putting a thermomter in the fridge is a good way to make a fridge test. I don't know how often you are at home during the day, but on a day off, you plan on being at home, I suggest a little HAACP test. Every hour or so, check the inside of your fridge. Put that thermomter way in the back, away from when you opne the fridge

The only edible salsa I've found so far is the Maria Dolores brand, sold at Globus in Basel.  Not fantastic like what you can get in California and pretty expensive, but definitely decent stuff.   
Globus Basel also has guacamole in the refrigerated section.  It's ok, especially if you add some chopped onions and a bit of lemon to freshen up the flavor.   
But beware the Globus store-brand salsas they just came out with:  while the Tortilla-Salsa Mojito is not bad (it's sweet though, so best for tex-mex dishes), what they call the regular Tortilla Salsa was inedible and tasted of pure vinegar -- I'd say it's way worse than the imported fake salsa from the US grocery stores (Old El Paso, etc.) that's pretty much ubiquitous at Swiss grocery stores.  It was more expensive than the Maria Dolores salsas and I put it straight into the trash after one taste.

another hearty Swiss-style meal is bratwurst with onion gravy. Fry up a couple of veal or pork bratwurst, then remove from pan. In the same pan, brown several sliced onions for a few minutes, add some white wine, then water and the Bratensauce thing Ed mentioned. Simmer, add salt and pepper to taste, add bratwurst at the end. Serve with Maccaroni or Roesti and salad. 
Of course, you'd be smart to intersperse a diet of heavy Swiss-style food with something like this once in awhile:

I had something at the restaurant at Gasthaus Zur Sonne somewhere around Luzern (real specific I know!  )... it was a merengue omlette   that had Grand Marnier in it and it was served "soft" - hot but raw in the middle, fried on the outside, just like an egg omlette but without yolks and sweet and alcoholic.    
It was quite tasty, never heard of it before, it is a specialty apparently of the chef there... and I can not remember what it was called.

But can one still consider it borscht without all the good stuff??    
I had some version of it when I was visiting some relatives in Latvia ("no we are not Russians!") and it was pretty tasty. I remember lots of veggies in it, maybe a bit of sausage or something. And the sour cream.

Totally agree on making sure the fridge is cold enough - I realised after several weeks that the moving-out tenant had turned it to the 'warmest' setting, and we need it close to the coldest setting...   
We keep almost all the fruit/veg in the fridge nowadays, and have a separate freezer...   
On the 'up' side I have found lots of things that keep a lot longer than back 'ome' in Sydney - since the humidity is lower here, the breakfast cereals last for weeks without going 'stale', even if we don't bother to curl down the packets inside the box
Or you can use the Heston Blumenthal method - freeze the stock then let it defrost through muslin into a bowl. Very slow, but absolutely crystal clear and delicious.

All my flat mates have been cooks/chefs. They never abused my treasured kitchen knives but I did have to recover some of them from corresponding restaurants  .   
You don't really have to have top of the line expensive knives to cut things. I've been in a number of kitchens with sleek Wustofs that were so dull they would barely cut butter. No point in that! What's important is to have sharp knives.   
Get whatever knife set suits your aesthetic sense and your budget and spend a little on some sharpening equipment. I use stones, some like automatic sharpeners. Check Youtube for knife sharpening videos- it's not hard to do by hand.

I've shared this recipe with people in the past, and have no objection to sharing, but I've always let people watch me make a batch or two. The issue is that you cook the butter and sugar until it reaches a certain color, and I've never been successful trying to adapt it to using a candy thermometer. The color was described as a "warm tan" in the recipe I got from my aunt, but I like to think of it as "golden oak." It you cook it too long, it cracks your teeth. Not long enough and it isn't properly crunchy.   
The other caveat: measurements are in cups and pounds/ounces.   
But PM me if you want to experiment with it.

Espresso geeks are a bit like audio geeks, which is why there's a market for machines costing thousands of francs. With Birchermüesli, it's the same as with cheese Fondue: Everbody thinks his own recipe is the best. I therefore only add one that I found on the Web.   
   Ingredients for four people:   
      * 4 tablespoons oat flakes 
      * 8 tablespoons water 
      * 4 tablespoons sweet evaporated milk or cream 
      * Honey or sugar according to taste (use as little sugar as possible) 
      * Juice of 2 lemons 
      * 8 apples    
  Method:   
     1. Put oat flakes, water, sweet evaporated milk and juice of lemon in a bowl. 
     2. Wash apples, cut in pieces, remove core (do not remove skin!) 
     3. Grind apples into the bowl and mix well. 
     4. Add sugar and honey according to your own taste and mix well again.   
  Variations:   
      * Use plain yogurt instead of water and evaporated milk. 
      * Add cream, half and half or milk according to taste. 
      * Include any kind of berry, oranges or other fruit instead of, or in addition to, the apples.   
  Add 2 to 3 tablespoons of ground almonds and/or hazelnuts     
Source: Look  , you'll also get some additional information about Birchermüesli.

ahh, Blutwurst and Leberwurst with Sauerkraut and potato salad...a true Swiss delicacy, I refer to it as the equivalent of "Swiss Sushi". Dijon mustard and a glass of Sauser completes this dish.   
Preparation is very easy: boil a pot of salted water, SWITCH OFF the burner, drop the sausages into the hot water, unpricked, straight from the package. Leave for 5-8 minutes in the hot water with burner off, depending on how congealed you want the blood sausage.   
Perfect, minimum effort.

post:
Just sub bittersweet choc with white chocolate, and halve the recipe for a start. Enjoy!     
Chocolate Pastry Cream  
Recipe from Chocolate Desserts by Pierre Hermé   
 2 cups (500g) whole milk 
 4 large egg yolks 
 6 tbsp (75g) sugar 
 3 tablespoons cornstarch, sifted 
 7 oz (200g) bittersweet chocolate, preferably Velrhona Guanaja, melted 
 2½ tbsp (1¼ oz: 40g) unsalted butter, at room temperature   
1) In a small saucepan, bring the milk to a boil.  In the meantime, combine the yolks, sugar and cornstarch together and whisk in a heavy‐bottomed saucepan.   
2) Once the milk has reached a boil, temper the yolks by whisking a couple spoonfuls of the hot milk into the yolk mixture.Continue whisking and slowly pour the rest of the milk into the tempered yolk mixture.   
3) Strain the mixture back into the saucepan to remove any egg that may have scrambled.  Place the pan over medium heat and whisk vigorously (without stop) until the mixture returns to a boil. Keep whisking vigorously for 1 to 2 more minutes (still over medium heat).Stir in the melted chocolate and then remove the pan from the heat.   
4) Scrape the pastry cream into a small bowl and set it in an ice‐water bath to stop the cooking process. Make sure to continue stirring the mixture at this point so that it  remains smooth.   
5) Once the cream has reached a temperature of 140 F remove from the ice‐water bath and stir in the butter in three or four installments. Return the cream to the ice‐water bath to continue cooling, stirring occasionally, until it has completely cooled. The cream is now ready to use or store in the fridge.   
Notes: 
1) The pastry cream can be made 2‐3 days in advance and stored in the refrigerator.   
2) In order to avoid a skin forming on the pastry cream, cover with plastic wrap pressed onto the cream.   
3) Tempering the eggs raises the temperature of the eggs slowly so that they do not scramble.

We do, most often fish stock. It is actually easy and quick (with some planning) and cheap as you can get fish carcasses for free from a fishmonger. We use it to make this fish stew from River Café's cookbook which is much simpler to do than bouillabaisse or other mediterranean soups. You can also freeze it and use later for seafood risotto.    
I also make this very simple and quick vegetable soup, especially in the evening:    
Peel and cut one onion and cook in little olive oil until soft 
Add a splash of white wine and boil for a few seconds 
Add 1-2 peeleed potatoes cut in chunks and some boiled water from a kettle 
At this stage you can also add some spices: dried dill and a bit of mild curry work well; you can also add a crushed clove of garlic 
When potatoes are half-cooked (this will be in about 10 minutes), add a few handfulls of frozen garden peas 
Cook for another 5 minutes or so to make sure that potatoes are soft and peas remain bright green 
Blitz in a blender until smooth 
Adjust seasoning 
Thin with some milk or cream if it is too thick, although it works well on its own 
Add some finely chopped fresh dill to add more fragrance   
And that's it. Everybody in my family loves it.

Basically you get an empty glass, lay a tea spoon over the edge, add a cube of sugar, pour 4 cl of Absinthe over the sugar cube, then light the sugar with a lighter, leave it for around 30 to 60 sec, then turn the spoon to let the sugar drop into the drink & dissolve it.   
2 of these drinks & you're done for the night

I was forgetting something "special" my dad used to do for chili. His chili is self-described as "tasty" (which you can take to mean that you probably need a towel because it is   hot).   
My dad used to buy a "small" chuck roast, cut it into small cubes and marinate over night in hot salsa. The next day he'd sear the meet in a heavy pot and then add in the onions and whatever fresh peppers he wanted to use. I think he added another jar of hot salsa instead of crushed or diced tomatoes (or maybe in addition to) along with a few cans of pinto beans.     
There was a restaurant we'd go to in Orlando (chain though, called Sweet Tomatoes) that had 6 - 10 (I forget exactly  ) different kinds of chili, including some made with venison, chicken, turkey, or buffalo rather than beef... some was really good.

If you like mildly sweet milky tea, sweetened condensed milk works great with Ceylon tea or English Breakfast.   
Or make  :   
Stir over medium-low heat a non-stick saucepan filled with 150g dessicated coconut milk, 2/3 can of sweetened condensed milk, 1/2 tsp cardamom powder and half a cup of sugar. Cook until it's a very sticky lump. Turn out into a pan lined with baking paper. Press down the coconut mixture with another piece of the paper (it's hot!). Cut into squares when cool.  Very yummy, but addictive!

Hi Subh,   
My advice would be to buy a Swiss cookery book and try out the recipes yourself. If you want to know if the recipes are 'authentic', dine at Swiss restaurants or invite Swiss friends over to verify, compare and comment.    
My father in law, who is a 100% Zürcher, cooks exactly according to recipes by Betty Bossi and he swears by her.   
Also look for the following books:     Switzerland - A Culinary Tour (2006) Peter Widmer   Swiss Cooking (2003) Michael Klein, Yvonne Tempelmann   Swiss Roestis (2003) by Stefan Stich   Valais Cooking (2008) Irma Dütsch, Roland Puippe   Zermatt for Gourmets (2006) Annette Weber, Marcus Gyger   Lake Lucerne Cooking (2006) Erica Bänziger, Claudio Zemp   St. Gallen Cooking (2006) Kurt Hanselmann   Zurich Cooking (2006) Robert Haupt   Graubünden Cooking (2007) Jacky Donatz, Chasper Pult   Berner Oberland Cooking (2007) Urs Wandeler, Elsbeth Hobmeier   
I use a book called 'Cooking in Switzerland' by Marianne Kaltenbach and it is excellent.   
Happy Cooking !

I discovered that Beerplanet Lowe sells the Doggy Style Classic APA, from the Flying Dog Brewery.   
And IMHO it is great.   
When opening the bottle you are welcomed by an explosion of hop flavours (mostly C-hops), smells like Grapefruit/Orange/Lemon, beautiful!   
The colour is orange/copper and the malty, slightly sweet aftertaste is the perfect balance for the strong hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is also very nice.   
I was lucky to have a rather young bottle, probably the hop aromas will reduce over time.   
Anyway, if you like the American style (craft) brews, I absolutely recommend it.

That French waiter is most simply wrong, completely wrong. Most of intercontinental wine freighting is done by airfreight. I have brought wines home from many holidays by air, and kept quite many bottles in the cellar for long times, and they did not suffer. However, what people often forget is that the many wines from "holidays" countries are excellent but not supposed to be stored for months or even years. Wines from Egypt for example ought to be consumed within some four months. You can store wines from Lebanon and Israel for years, but not wines from Tunisia or Algeria. Wines from Morocco can be stored for one year and two but not more. Much in fact does not depend on the wines but on the caps (corks etc). If you take any wine home by air or car or train, you have to put it into the cellar for at least three days or rather a week or two. And not store the bottle(s) upright but neither fully even but with the upper side slightly higher up.    
Many Australian wines are cultivated in Australia by French emigrants, and are very similar to French wines. But the names differ, they may sound the same but the meaning of the terms does not correspond. You also have to consider the "terroir" which means the ground which in Australia is rather different from the one in most of France. I think that the wine you brought round to France was of a sort not to the liking of French people.        The prices of Duty Free Shops have to be higher than those of wine stores due to the expensive infrastructure and the fact that the airport companies get a fixed percentage not of the profit but of the total price. And the choice of duty free shops usually is not exactly impressive.

Try this:   Old fashioned lemonade   75g (1½lb) Sugar 
1.2lt (2 pints) Water 
4 Lemons 
2 tsp Citric Acid 
2 tsp Tartaric Acid    Finely peel the lemons, removing only the outer waxy layer and squeeze the juice. 
Place the water into a saucepan with the lemon rind and boil for 2 - 3 minutes. 
Place the sugar, lemon juice, citric acid and tartaric acid into a bowl. 
Strain the boiling water over the juice mixture. 
Stir in the sugar to dissolve. 
Pour the liquid into clean, dry bottles sealing securely. 
Will keep for up to 6 weeks if stored in a cool dark place.   Can be diluted before serving.   
It wont last 6 weeks though

I love the little rabbit fillets on baby leaf salad.   
Make your salad as you like it.   
Fry the fillets with smoked bacon cubes and mushrooms add garlic and freshly chopped flat leaf parsley. slice fillets and scatter all hot ingredients over the salad. Serve with crusty bread.   
An alternative:   
Clean and chop chicken livers into small pieces.   
Season and dust with flour.   
Fry fast and furiously on a high heat until the outside is brown and crispy. 
Add to fave salad.   
Croutons can be added to both dishes if desired.

On the island of Okinawa Japan, the local bars serve an interesting drink called Habu Saki. It is basically a jar of rice wine with a couple of large highly venomous snakes floating in it. The idea is that the venom of the snake infused in the saki produces a hallucinogenic effect.   
When I saw the jar, the snakes had apparently been in there for quite some time as it was cloudy and there were scales floating in it. After quite a bit of liquid courage, My friends and I each ordered up a shot. I don't remember hallucinating. Come to think of it, I don't remember much of anything after drinking it. But the hangover the next day was epic in its brilliance.   
Dougal's eating a scorpion is where I draw the line. No way, never , it's not going to happen! Scorpions are my achilles heel, along with live octopus of course. These are the two creatures in this world that make me want to run, or swim, in the opposite direction as fast as I can!

In Marktkauf just across the border from Basel is an Indian shop that has good packets of curry for reasonable price.  Tip: peal off the label and you get the English instructions.     
Anyway, here's something to go with your curry;   
Boil some brocolli ( cut into about 1" size ).  Chop some red peppers, and some onions. ( I'm talking about enough for four people ).   
Fry the onions, adding in 1-2 tsp cumin and 0.5-1 tsp turmeric.  When the onions soften, crush about 2 tsps of cardamom pods, add them in, with the peppers and brocolli.   
Cook for about 10-15 mins, according to whether you like crunchy veg or a soggy mass.

I second that for peanut oil - high smoke point (   ). As for potatoes, I seek out for   whenever possible or alternatively the Spunta.      
Suggested Recipe   
Russet burbank ( ), with its floury texture and low moisture content, makes the perfect chip, but you can also use bintje or spunta.   
INGREDIENTS   
1kg russet burbank potatoes, peeled 
peanut oil, for deep-frying       
METHOD   
Cut potatoes lengthways into 1cm slices; cut each slice lengthways into 1cm-wide pieces. Stand potato pieces in large bowl of cold water for 30 minutes to avoid discolouration. Drain; pat dry with absorbent paper.    
Heat oil in deep-fryer, wok or large saucepan; cook chips, in 3 batches, about 4 minutes each or until just tender but not browned. Drain on absorbent paper; stand 10 minutes.   
Reheat oil; cook chips, in 3 batches, separating any that stick together by shaking deep-fryer basket or with a slotted spoon, until crisp and golden brown. Drain on absorbent paper.    
TIPS  After the first cooking, the chips can stand for several hours before the final deep-frying.   
Corn oil or vegetable oil can also be used.   
Good luck.

There's no federal and little cantonal regulation about going out. I've found some information about Lausanne (which is the biggest city of Vaud):   
I doubt that all rules are regularly enforced, but teenagers aged 12-15 and younger need written permission from their guardian to frequent restaurants and bars without him. With permission they're allowed to stay in these venues until 20:00. Some bars and the night clubs don't allow guests under 18.   
After 22:00, teenagers under 18 are only allowed outside to walk home.   
Sources:             
Alcohol on the other hand is regulated mostly at the federal level. Beer and wine are sold to 16 years old and older. Liquor and alcopops to 18+ years old. This applies to both restaurants and shops. Ticino is stricter and sells all alcohol only to 18+.      You got around in your early years!

post:
I detect cynicism and distrust in many of these posts. Surely anyone looking at the cost comparisons are only fooling themselves: there's a   why the non-organic food is cheaper.   
My 98 year old Grandmother - raised on a farm, never been ill in her life - wonders why non-Bio food isn't labelled as such. Surely she's right.   
"This food is   Bio, but hey, it's 12% cheaper"       
Food   be expensive. Most of us are spoilt on excessive consumption, especially concerning food. We even manage to throw 30% of it away, yet we say Bio is expensive! Weird.   
We blindly follow the price of things and rarely the value. It is possible to live happily on a Bio / Organic diet, even on a low budget. One learns to economise. Millions of generations before us managed.   
I doubt there's much mileage in taste, though. Fresher, unpolluted produce is certainly going to make a difference, but not to the average Joe.   
Once again, the public gets what the public wants, which is low prices - oh and I'll have a free carrier bag while I'm at it.   
Every purchase one makes is a political decision. Shame we're not educated more on these themes, but it ain't as sexy as a free child's toy and bigger, juicier burgers...   
Political movements are never top-down. It takes grass-roots support - as in,   doing something about it - which causes momentum and eventual political shift.    
Still, I'm alright, Jack

post:
You have a mocha coffee pot.   
Turn on the hob, if it's electric. You want it hot.   
Add water to the level marked on the inside of the lower section. Ideally use freshly milled coffee beans and add enough to reasonably fill the filter (which you've now placed in the lower section).    
Don't dampen the grounds, it's not necessary. Screw on the upper section, good 'n' tight. (Have a supply of spare rubber rings as these seals wear - widely available, about CHF3.-).   
Heat cups.   
Allow water and heat to do their business until you hear it pop-pop-pop-popping. Take off the heat and allow the magic to settle.    
Don't let it sit on the heat once it's started pop-pop-pop-popping, or you'll get a burnt taste and that ain't allowed.   
Your valve on the side is only necessary if there's a block in the filter. It'll trip if necessary and release any pressure. Best to stick around for the first few times you do it    
Don't clean with detergent, just rinse. That sweet oilyness coats the metal and keeps the flavour just so. First times you use the pot, pour the coffee out and 'wear it in' so to say.   
Mmm, coffee.

No need for the greaseproof paper - just brush the bottom of the tray with oil first. Don't pre-heat the try because I found that the chips then stick. Place chips flat on the try and not touching. Use two trays if necessary.   
Cook with the upper grill on your oven with the tray up high at 190°C for around 20 mins or until the chips start to brown. Thin chips will be quicker. Turn with an egg flipper and cook again until brown. Yes, it is much slower than with a fryer. You can also do wedges in their skins - no need for peeling potatoes! Great with sweet chilli sauce and sour cream. Yum. I usually use Victoria potatoes for roasting here too. Migros had 5kg for CHF 5 this week.

You often see these guys around, there is often one on Thawil high street. They sometimes even make the cheese themselves, or at least know the family that does and the prices are always much cheaper than supermarkets for equivalent cheese. Like a proper cheese shop or market stall, they will always let you try first, and you don't need much local language to do that!   
It's difficult to recommend mild (or non smelly Swiss cheeses in general), even some young ones can sometimes have quite a whiff. Generally, I would go for paler fleshed cheeses or Gruyer.  Of course, you should always keep your cheese in an air tight food container in the fridge to stop it drying out anyway.   
One Swiss cheese I can recommend though is San Carlo BIO from Graubunden, a lot of good cheese shops will stock it. It's pale, creamy, mild and very morish.

Well at home and with a glass of wine next to the computer  , I did a few calculations on the energy efficiency of the human body. 
  It is generally accepted that, of the 2300 calories we need in a day, we use 60% of the energy for the basic metabolism (heart beat, respiration, keeping the body temperature), 30% for activities (moving, working, thinking) and 10% for digestion of the foodstuff. The excess above 2300 is stored as fat. This opens for a few interesting observations: 
  Increased physical activity will work only on the 30% of the daily expenditure. One hour at the gym will do very little for you on the overall daily energy expenditure (as it works only on the 30% of the total). Just as well to park oneself in front of the TV…honest, I'm not kidding!   
  Why not look for a strategy that addresses the 60% of the basic metabolism? Now, much of the basic metabolism aims at keeping us warm (I know, I’m just trying to keep it simple!). The metabolic reactions that help regulate body temperature will increase if we are in a cold environment, jut to keep us warm, or decrease if the environment is warm. On the other hand, we will also radiate heat if absolutely still, this is heat generated by chemical reactions in the body that aim at keeping us alive. Laboratory experiments have shown that in a warm environment (hot room or hot bath etc, no physical activity) we loose around 20 calories/hour as heat in order to avoid overheating. In a somewhat colder environment we will loose about 80 calories/hour (no physical activity). 
Now, think of the situation hot bedroom and thick, Swiss style duvet.     In the one case (hot bedroom and duvet), the body uses up 20 Calories per hour for the 8 hours of sleep, or a total of around 160 Calories during the night. In the other case (thin covers, cool room) the body uses up the more natural 80 Calories per hour of sleep for those 8 hours or 640 Calories during the night. The difference of these two situations appears to be 480 Calories per night.    A pound of fat contains 3500 calories. Simple maths will tell you that you can loose a pound of fat every week if you put that duvet away, open the bedroom window and go to sleep!
Have a good night's sleep!

ok here goes       
1 tsp cumin seeds 
1 tsp coriander seeds 
5 black peppercorns, left whole  
2 green cardamom pods, seeds only 
2 cloves 
1cm/½in piece cinnamon 
1cm/½in piece ginger, peeled and chopped 
7 garlic cloves, peeled and left whole 
2 - 4 large fresh red chillies (depending on preference, i used 2 large chillies and it was still a bit too hot) 
3 tbsp white wine vinegar  
pinch salt 
about 400g of pork cubed, pork with some fat on works best to allow the curry to cook in its natural juices 
3tbsp oz vegetable oil 
1 medium onion, finely sliced       
1. Using a spice grinder or pestle and mortar, grind the cumin seeds, coriander seeds, peppercorns, cardamom seeds, cloves and cinnamon to a fine powder. 
2. In a food processor, blend the ginger, garlic, chillies and white wine vinegar to a paste.  
3. Mix the ground spice mixture with the paste until well combined and season with a pinch of salt. Rub the mixture all over the pork using your fingers, then set the pork aside, covered, to marinate for 1½-2 hours. (recommend using some plastic gloves to rub the marinade in) 
4. Heat the oil in a non-stick pan. When the oil is hot, add the onion and fry for 5-7 minutes, or until golden-brown and soft.  
5. Add the marinated pork pieces and fry for 6-7 minutes, turning once, until golden-brown on all sides. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pan with a lid and cook for 35-40 minutes, stirring occasionally, or until the pork is tender. Add small splashes of boiling water to the pan as necessary if the juices in the pan dry out. (if your pork has enough fat you will not need to add any water) Add as little water as possible as the resulting sauce should be quite thick.   
This recipe is copied and pasted from BBC food but I have edited it slightly

post:
To convert recipes to use dry yeast, use 40% of the weight of fresh yeast - in other words, use 20 gr. dry yeast in place of 50 gr. fresh yeast (.4 X 50 gr.).   
To convert recipes to use fresh yeast, divide the weight of dry yeast by 40% - so, use 100 gr. fresh yeast in place of 40 gr. dry yeast (.4/40 gr.).  One other important factor is the liquid.  Dry yeast must be dissolved in 4 times its weight of water.  That means, if you are replacing 40 gr. of dry yeast, then reduce the water in the recipe by 160 gr.   
Hope this helps... 
Jack

Make this the day before because a head will form overnight. 
Serves 8: 
6 eggs separated 
1 pint whipping cream 
1 quart milk 
3 /4 cup sugar   
Beat egg whites until stiff 
Beat whipped cream until stiff 
Beat egg yokes until lemony   
Pour milk, sugar and yokes in serving bowl 
Add 1 cup brandy (or rum) and mix.   
Fold in egg whites and whipped cream.  Sprinkle with nutmeg. 
Put in the fridge overnight.

I have a special jug that lets you separate the fat from the meat juices. After the roast is out of the oven I pour the juices into the jug and pour off the juice into a saucepan.   
To that, I add the water I used to parboil my roast potatoes in and add a beef stock cube. This I thicken up to gravy using cornflour. To prevent lumps, put a tablespoon of cornflour in a bowl, and mix it to a thin paste with water. Then whisk that gradually into your gravy mixture as you heat it gently to just below boiling point.   
I am sure this will have Escoffier turning in his...(well)...gravy.   
HTH. 
Nick

Feeling nostalgic for the afternoon scones we had in Wales last month, a couple of days ago I decided to try a buttery, flaky scones recipe in a Hastings House book. Well, it turned out to be very, very delicious. Adding currants or dried cranberries or not is entirely up to you (NO icing topping or choc chips, thanks!).   
NO-EGG Flaky Scones   
2 cups all-purpose flour 
1 tablespoon baking powder 
1/2 teaspoon salt 
2 tbs sugar 
5 tbs unsalted butter, cold, cut in chunks 
1 cup whipping cream 
1 cup currants or dried cranberries 
whipping cream for brushing the scones and to serve   
Method: 
Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (195-200 degrees C). 
Mix with a whisk in a big bowl the flour, bpowder, salt, sugar. 
Cut in butter with a butter knife in each hand until  mix looks like coarse crumbs. 
Pour in cream and fold in everything until just incorporated. Do NOT overmix. 
If mixture seems a little dry, add a little more cream. 
Fold currants or cranberries into batter. 
Press the dough in 3 or 4 batches on lightly floured board 1 1/4-inch (3cm) thick. Cut into triangles. All in all about 8-16 scones, depending on size (enough for 4 hungry mouths). 
Place scones on ungreased cookie sheet. Brush tops with a bit of cream. 
Bake for 15-20 minutes until golden brown.     
(I don't have to say how to serve them. They even taste wonderful on their own. If you want a great orange-grapefruit marmalade recipe from the same book, send me a PM.)

My mom's traditional Taiwanese pickled Kohlrabi -   
Peel. Slice into thin (approx. 1cm thick) stripes. Put the stripes into a bowl and sprinkle salt.  Thoroughly mix the salt and Kohlrabi with your hand and let it stand for 15-20 minutes.   
The salt will draw the liquid from the veggie - drain the liquid and taste the slices, if too salty rinse quickly with cold water; drain.   
Put a dash or sugar, a teaspoon (or more if you like it spicy) of Chinese garlic chile paste, and a dash of sesame oil; toss to coat. Chill in the fridge for 20-30 minutes then serve   
Optional - garnish with chopped cilantro (coriander).   
This tastes awesome as an appetizer or accompaniment with any Asian dish. As a kid I used to eat just this with white rice...

Oopsy, just copy/pasted, didn't see the formatting was waaay off. That strange language is HG (high german). It says:   
"Making cheese in your own kitchen   
Starting making cheese is identical with making cottage cheese. Here too milk is mixed with a fermenting culture and présure. Of course our healthy ProBiDa-culture is perfectly fit for it. Therefore add to the cottage cheese or yoghurt machine following: 
- 1 measuring spoon ProBiDa 
- 1/2 présure tab (dissolved in a bit of water) 
- 1 liter 3.5% pasteurized or frischmilch 
- wait for 14-16 hours   
In this time the milk sours and sets up. To get the whey out of the solids (casein), the cheesecurd needs to be cut up. You don't necessarily need a cheeseharp, a bread knife will do to cut 1cm x 1cm squares."   
With the fermenting culture is meant a fresh yogurt with live lactobacilli.   
Another interesting fact: Rohmilch is cooled down immediately to 6°C after milking to slow bacterial growth to keep the milk from turning sour. In fact, the milk is unlikely to be heated by the farmer, but by the cooperative laitière or Emmi.   Might be a good idea to ask the farmer if he pasteurises himself.

For anyone who has a garden, growing your own garlic is a great option. It is not difficult, but you need to plant them in autumn, not in spring. They will come above ground in January and should be ready in May/June.   
They are difficult to grow in pots though, you would need deep containers with well drained soil. Anyway, if you are really after the freshest garlic, it might be the best option.   and it is fun too, they grow fast!

If in doubt, try Globus.   
Happy hunting!

What you really want to do is crush the garlic your preferred way (myself I put a fork on top then pounce on it with a the wooden knife of a handle) in a saucer with a generous dose of salt. Add little water and stir (not beat...) for a while until it gets all salty (yeah I see the chuckling at the back...) and garlicky. Pour generously over fries, meat etc. It works best with fries as their spongy texture will absorb the stuff really well. This will positively ensure that even your sweat will reek of garlic for at least two days.

Yeah, I know this is a pretty blatant ad, but I think I spent enough time in bars with the people on this forum to get away with it    
Anyway, we (Google) just launched Google Maps for Switzerland! (at last!)   
What does that mean? After all, you could see maps of Zurich before right? And we've had hi-res aerial imagery for a while now.   
Well, it means: There are a bunch of other features that existed before today, but you might not have been aware of. For example, do you like classical music? Try searching for "flute recital lucerne" - at the bottom you'll find a placemark added to the map by somebody else (ie, it's not from a directory) marking the location of a James Galway recital.    
Anybody can add their own marks to the map like that - check out "trout in lake konstanz" for another example.   
One last thing - you can access the Swiss-localized version of the site by using    
Have fun!

Hi,   
Crumpets are relatively easy to make at home. Here is the recipe I use:   
8 oz (225 g) strong plain flour (CH: Halbweiss or Hellesurdinkel work) 
1 level teaspoon salt 
1 level tablespoon dried yeast 
1 level teaspoon caster sugar 
½ pint (275 ml) milk   
Sieve the flour into a mixing bowl. Mix in the salt, sugar and dried yeast.   
Heat the milk gently until it is lukewarm.   
Make a well in the flour mix and whisk in the milk a bit at a time, make sure you get rid of any lumps. An electric whisk might be an idea.   
Cover the bowl with a teatowel and leave in a warm place for about 45 minutes for the batter to rise - it will double in size.   
For cooking, -I have some "rösti rings" I bought ages ago, otherwise round cookie cutters or egg rings will work. Make sure you grease them on the inside with plenty of butter.   
Place the rings in a heavy frying pan on a medium heat. When they are hot, spoon in about a tablespoon of batter to each ring. Let cook for 4-5 mins until bubbles appear on the top surface of the batter. Then remove the rings and flip the crumpets over to cook the topside.   
Place the cooked crumpets in a warm oven to stop them cooling.   
Each time you cook a batch, make sure you grease the rings and they and the pan are hot enough.   
Cheers, 
Nick

Not sure when I'll be baking the next batch so in the meantime heres the recipe kindly copied out from the Green and Blacks chocolate cookbook by my friend.     Celebration Brownies! 
bits you need: 
200g unsalted butter
100g dark choc -min 60% cocoa solids-broken up
350g dark soft brown sugar
4 large eggs
1 teaspoon vanilla extract (DONT USE FLAVOURING!!) 
200g self raising flour (or make from 200g plain flour + 1 tsp baking powder)
pinch of salt
280g box of celebrations - or Malteasers or mint choc thins
baking tin 11x7inch/ 28x18cm  
preheat oven to 180C/350F/gas mark 4 
brush tin with melted butter & line with greaseproof paper 
melt butter & choc in "heatproof" bowl suspended over saucepan of barely simmering water (Dont over heat chocolate - take your time & take it off the heat!) remove from heat & add sugar  
beat eggs & vanilla essence & add to choc mix (make sure its cooled down else choc omelette!) sift the flour into the with the salt 
unwrap chocs and pour half of mix into tin & position chocs so that at least one per portion once cut (just fit in as many as you can!) pour in remaining mix and ensure chocs are covered.  
bake for approx 25-20 mins until top is crispy & inside soft (let it finish baking in the tin once you have that fab broken top! Dont be tempted to cook more!)  
leave to cool in tin before cutting 
EAT!!!!     En Guete!
